subsection.heading: 1 Introduction: empirical boundaries of the construction
1.1 Double objects in dative alternations
subsection.p: The representational status and proper derivation of double object constructions have long been a subject of debate in generative grammar. Most of the controversies stem from the fact that many languages from different families display a ‘dative alternation’, although complements to verbs in these languages normally follow a relatively fixed word order. That is, an indirect object may appear either as the object of a preposition or as one of two noun phrase objects of the verb, the other being the direct object. In the latter configuration, neither has any indication of oblique case or PP status.

Many studies have analyzed the English double object construction and its close relatives in other languages. This review will summarize and evaluate a number of these, beginning with Fillmore's (1965) classic study, continuing through some Relational Grammar studies and Government and Binding analyses such as those by Kayne (1981c) and Larson (1988b). Our comparative presentation and integrated conclusions crucially depend on accounts of dative and applicative alternations in several non-Indo-European languages. We terminate by covering some later analyses such as Den Dikken (1995c) and Pesetsky (1995).

However, our review of the massive literature on double objects doesn't pretend to be exhaustive. We regret that we could not include the most recent materials on the topic or a number of unpublished works. Nor do our short summaries really do justice to the many long and detailed studies. Rather we give a taste of each proposal, focusing as often as not on what we perceive as weaknesses rather than strengths, and try to extract certain cross-linguistic descriptive generalizations.
The sentences in (1) exemplify Fillmore's (1965) TO-dative alternation and those of (2) his FOR-dative pattern: 1

(1)
a. Mary sent a present to each family member.
b. Mary sent each family member a present.

(2)
a. Carolyn baked that cake for my children.
b. Carolyn baked my children that cake.

It is important to observe that double object constructions encompass only patterns where neither of two NPs in a verb's complement system is a predicate nominal. That is, each object must stand in a different semantic relation with the verb (or be assigned different theta-roles). In traditional terms, the two NPs are direct object and indirect object (DO and IO). In contrast, the example in (3) does not contain double objects. Rather, it exemplifies secondary predication, where a predicate nominal follows and modifies the direct object. The syntax of predicate nominals differs greatly from object NPs; cf. Emonds (1985: ch. 6) for a discussion of seven differences:
(3) The Jets {called, considered, declared, judged, named} Officer Krupke a fink.

It has been often observed that head-initial SVO languages that lack a dative alternation, such as some well-studied Romance languages, nonetheless contain exact counterparts of (3). Oehrle (1976) proposes that the same phrase structure rule can generate both secondary predication and double objects. However, following the demise of language-particular phrase structure rules, most analysts agree that these two kinds of double NP constructions are related neither empirically nor theoretically. Consequently, we will not further analyze secondary predication or predicate nominals.
The following typical examples of double object constructions alternating with DO-PP are respectively from Baker (1988a: ch. 5) and Chung (1976):

(4)
Chiche
a:
a. Mbidzi zi-na-perek-a msampha kwa nkhandwe.
zebras SP-PAST-hand-ASP trap to fox
‘The zebras handed the trap to the fox.’
b. Mbidzi zi-na-perek-er-a nkhandwe msampha.
zebras SP-PAST-hand-APPL-ASP fox trap
‘The zebras handed the fox the trap.’

(5)
Indonesian:
a. Ali mem-beli telefisi untuk ibu- nja.
Ali TRN-buy television for mother-his
‘Ali bought a television for his mother.’
b. Ali mem-beli- kan ibu- nja telefisi.
Ali TRN-buy- APPL mother- his television
‘Ali bought his mother a television.’

In the (b), or double object, examples, the verb carries what is called an ‘applicative suffix’, a term borrowed from anthropological linguistics. This suffix marks the ‘promotion’ of an ordinarily oblique NP complement of an unmarked transitive verb to the direct object of that verb. Extending the terminology, it can be proposed that even verbs that are not overtly marked (English, Dutch, Mainland Scandinavian) can have null applicative inflections for indirect objects (section 2.5). Depending on whether the applicative suffix seems closer to a TO or a FOR dative, the literature usually refers to ‘dative applicatives’ (4) or ‘benefactive applicatives’ (5) respectively. We return briefly in section 3.4 to the structural position of this affix.

A dative alternation often occurs in SVO systems, but it can occur in V-final systems. Korean, a thoroughgoing head-final language, has speakers who accept a double accusative construction with an applicative auxiliary verb (Choe 1986). It thereby contrasts with its close syntactic cousin Japanese, also head-final, whose indirect objects must appear with a dative case marker. But with the exception of Korean and Dutch, it appears that almost all languages whose dative alternations have been scrutinized in widely available work are head-initial. Caseless double objects may thus have some affinity with head-initial systems, but we have not investigated this intriguing possibility.

Before turning to the more common SVO dative alternations, we summarize some results of two enlightening studies of double objects in the V-final system of Dutch, Haegeman (1985) for the West Flemish dialect and Den Dikken and Mulder (1991) for Standard Dutch. According to Haegeman, West Flemish treats double objects differently with two distinct verb classes, which are reminiscent of TO vs. FOR datives. 3 Unlike English and the many head-initial languages reviewed below, the indirect object of the TO dative can lack an overt P aan ‘to’ only if VP-internal (as one of two objects). Such an NP can neither passivize nor topicalize without P resurfacing. Consequently, she concludes “that the indirect object is a PP in all positions and that the prepositional head of the PP can be non-overt, . . . if and only if governed by a case-assigning verb” (1985: 285). If correct, this reinforces our suspicion that double objects involving truly bare indirect object NPs are limited to head-initial systems.

Den Dikken and Mulder's (1991) empirical arguments focus more on parasitic gaps and whether object scrambling in Dutch is an ‘A movement’ or an ‘A′ movement’ (read ‘A′’ as ‘A-bar’). Nonetheless, their structural conclusions about Dutch double objects are similar to Haegeman's. They argue that Dutch ‘bare’ indirect objects (those lacking an overt preposition) have the form [PP [P Ø] – DP] and are syntactically related to preverbal phrases [PP [P aan] − DP]. This ‘covert prepositional dative’ structure then accounts for why bare indirect objects do not freely bind parasitic gaps. Moreover, they echo Haegeman in noting that such PP structure also accounts for an inability to passivize, in clear contrast to the bare indirect objects of verb-initial systems. 4

Haegeman (1985) also examines an intriguing (though inexact) West Flemish counterpart to a FOR dative (with verbs such as trekken ‘pull’ and beloven ‘promise’), which seems to involve a bare NP adjunct similar to what traditional grammar often calls a “dative of interest.” She shows that these West Flemish NPs do clearly become nominative subjects of passive verbs, in contrast to Fillmore's observation about English FOR datives (see note 1). But she also argues that they originate outside the lowest verb phrase, that is, they are adjuncts of V′. If so, they again do not constitute an ‘object’ (i.e. a complement) in the sense focused on in this study.

As a review of existing treatments in the literature, the bulk of this chapter will necessarily concentrate on comparing those VO(O) systems which fail to distinguish their double objects either by case-marking or by an overt P. Our conclusions may or may not apply to double object constructions in head-final systems such as Dutch.

One descriptive generalization about such head-initial double object languages that has received little attention is that in every such language, the indirect object precedes the direct object if and only if subjects precede predicates. Typically, in well-studied SVO constructions, the indirect object must be first. But in Tzotzil, widely described as subject-final, the indirect object follows the direct (Aissen 1983: 286). This generalization suggests that, at some level, the indirect object may have a subject-like property. And although several analyses of double objects reviewed in section 4 treat indirect objects as deep subjects, it is not clear whether any of them can naturally express the apparent predicate–subject word order of Tzotzil double objects. For in order to do so, any subject-final word order would have to reflect a single factor, such as SPECIFIER position relative to a head. But concepts such as phrase-final specifiers are not discussed in these works.

subsection.heading: 1.2 Double objects not in dative alternations
subsection.p: A different sort of double object construction consists of co-occurring direct and oblique objects in languages with overt oblique morphological case(s), or ‘m-case’. Holmberg and Platzack (1995) show that Icelandic has m-case. The largest class of Icelandic triadic verbs, including give, send, and tell, takes a direct object marked with accusative case (‘A’) and an indirect object marked with dative (‘D’):

(6)
Jón gaf Ólafi bókna.
John gave Olaf (D) a-book (A)
‘John gave Olaf a book.’

Holmberg and Platzack carefully contrast double objects in Icelandic to double objects in Mainland Scandinavian, which lacks m-case. For example, Icelandic give-type verbs cannot take dative to-constructions, they allow DO–IO order under some circumstances, and either object may be passivized as a nominative (‘N’). These properties are almost the opposite of those found in Mainland Scandinavian and other systems that lack m-case, such as English:

(7)
a. *Eg gaf bók til Jóns.
I gave book to John
‘I gave a book to John.’
b. Jóns mun gefa bókina einhverju bókasafni.
John will give the-book some library
‘John will give the book to some library.’
c. Jóni var gefin bókin.
John (D) was given the-book (N)
‘John was given the book.’
d. Bókin var gefin Jóni.
the-book (N) was given John (D)
‘The book was given to John.’

In our view, Holmberg and Platzack make a methodological error at the outset: they assume that Icelandic's m-case provides a key for determining how to assign abstract case in double object constructions without m-case. In particular, they assume that IOs rather than DOs must receive structural case by some extra mechanism. It seems more likely that both morphological case and the other properties of Icelandic double objects (e.g., freer word order, restrictions on benefactives, at least partial complementary distribution with overt P constructions, differences in passivization and impersonal passives) result from some deeper structural difference between Icelandic and Mainland Scandinavian. In fact, several of these properties suggest that IOs with m-case are structurally PPs. 5

Taking this ‘fault line’ as crucial, we accordingly set empirical boundaries on this study as follows: except for subject and direct object argument NPs with so-called quirky case, we propose that object NPs with oblique case are generally PPs with null P. That is, the oblique m-cases of Icelandic, German, Latin, Slavic languages, and so on are morphological reflections of structural adpositions rather than reflexes of the dative alternation of section 1.1.

However, we do not claim that oblique m-case is an infallible indicator of PP status. 6 Obliquely case-marked object NPs that are not deep direct objects sometimes (but not typically) ‘advance’ to surface direct object position and hence may not be PPs in surface structure. According to Holmberg (1991b) such advancement occurs in Icelandic. In some languages an oblique case-marked NP may even be a deep direct object; for example, Faltz (1978) suggests that Walbiri dative-marked NPs can be structural direct objects. We thus claim only that NP arguments of Vs are base-generated as PPs, subjects or direct objects; there are no ‘bare NP’ indirect objects.

Reorderings and advancements of direct and oblique objects that are morphologically invariant – that is, that retain their m-cases or their overt Ps – are more likely due to scrambling than to a dative alternation. Scrambling typically (but not only) operates in languages that overtly mark NP case. For example, Den Dikken (1995c: section 4.6), building on Müller's (1992) discussion of German, argues that the latter “features no genuine Dative Shift. What appears to be Dative Shift is actually A′-scrambling of a zero-headed dative PP.” 7 We tentatively agree with this conclusion, although we cannot fully exclude that languages with overtly case-marked NPs could, upon investigation, reveal a non-scrambling dative alternation.
Den Dikken's argument is based on one line of thought in traditional grammar, to the effect that oblique cases other than genitive are alternative forms of PPs. We can state this as follows:

(8)
Structure-Dependent Case:
Double object constructions in which one object is marked with productive, overt oblique case always involve at least one structural PP.8

An alternative view of case assignment, espoused for example by Zaenen et al. (1985, henceforth ‘ZMT’), is that “Case can be assigned in (at least) three different ways”: case can be semantic, idiosyncratic, or structural (‘functional’). We might give this approach the name of ‘autonomous case theory’. 9 Such a theory would be less restrictive in the types of underlying structures that could be proposed for double object constructions. In particular, no underlying PP would have to be present for case assignment.

In this chaper, we reject any source of case other than the four structural case-assigners V, P, I, and D. Moreover we hold that any category that can assign case can do so only once. We offer six arguments for preferring this structure-dependent case theory to autonomous case theory:

(i) Overt and null P parallelism. In ‘four-case’ languages such as Classical Greek, German, and Icelandic, structure-dependent case (8) predicts correctly that the case of a bare second object in double object constructions – what is usually called ‘dative’ – should be whichever case is ordinarily assigned by overt P. 10 An autonomous case theory, by simply defining the indirect object's case as ‘dative’, makes no prediction as to what case is expected with overt Ps.

(ii) Oblique case complements of nouns and adjectives. Indo-European case systems suggest the following generalizations: V regularly assigns accusative case and P regularly assigns oblique case; N and A do not assign case but receive case (Stowell, 1981); and when an NP does not receive case from its expected case-assigner, some P often assigns case to NP by default. These observations almost certainly hold independently even in autonomous case theory. Structure-dependent case consists simply of maintaining that these statements are exceptionless. Since bare oblique case NPs among multiple complements are exactly those lacking ‘expected case-assigners’, we hypothesize null Ps to assign them. They should occur with essentially the same distribution as other PPs.

Consequently, since Ns and As have PP complements but not direct objects in a wide range of languages, we expect that Ns and As can also have oblique but not accusative complements. This general asymmetric pattern, a mystery in a framework of autonomous case, is confirmed in many languages; for example, German in Van Riemsdijk (1983a).

(iii) Restrictions on combining oblique cases. Because the Icelandic dative can appear either as a (specially marked) direct object or as an empty-headed PP, Icelandic can have ‘double datives’, so this combination does not decide between structure-dependent and autonomous case theories. But in unstipulated constructions, structure-dependent case (8) defines accusative as the unique case assigned by V to a direct object and associates bare oblique case with PP structures. Consequently, it predicts the cross-linguistic absence of both double accusatives (outside of predicate nominal agreement) and double genitive complements. A theory of autonomous case cannot make any such prediction, as in fact its proponents admit: “Some other gaps remain unexplained, however; for example, nothing in our account of case would prevent Icelandic from having GEN GEN or ACC ACC combinations in postverbal position” (ZMT: 480). 11

(iv) Syntactic patterning. If some syntactic restriction distinguishes between NP and PP, autonomous case theory predicts that any oblique case phrases should act as NPs. Under structure-dependent case, oblique NPs (except those arguably in unique subject and object positions) should pattern rather with PPs. Here are two examples:

(a) The French relative pronoun qui as an object of P refers only to animate antecedents, but otherwise is indifferent to the value of this feature. When qui follows the dative marker à ‘to’, it is animate, i.e., the oblique phrase à qui acts like a PP (C. Piera, p.c.).

(b) A small class of discourse markers such as wa ‘topic’ and mo ‘too’ in Japanese immediately follow maximal phrases of any type (Kuroda 1965). Phrase-final nominative and accusative case markers ga and o on NP must delete in the presence of these discourse markers, but head P such as e ‘to’ or kara ‘from’ do not. The dative case marker ni, like Ps but unlike NP case-markers, appears with these discourse markers.
In both these examples, a structure-dependent case theory makes correct predictions, but autonomous case theory does not.

(v) Quantifier floating. We are not aware of a systematic cross-linguistic study, but the literature variously indicates that quantifier floating off obliquely case-marked NPs is less acceptable. In our view, this tendency is explained because oblique NPs are embedded in PPs. Hence they do not c-command a modifying quantifier located outside the PP. See section 3.2.6. 12

(vi) Undergoing NP movement. Structure-dependent case holds that an oblique case NP complement is usually a PP with an empty head. It then follows that except for direct objects with a ‘quirky case’ (as in Icelandic), oblique object NPs should not be able to structurally substitute for subject NPs; they should only topicalize like a deep PP. In confirmation of our hypothesis for oblique objects, ZMT (sections 3–5) observes precisely this contrast: “Thus the same type of tests that show that oblique NPs can be grammatical subjects in Icelandic show that the German analogues cannot be analyzed as such” (ZMT: 478).

We thus take structure-dependent case as established in the rest of this study. Each V and P can assign only one case, whether or not the case is morphologically overt. V usually assigns accusative but sometimes can assign an oblique ‘quirky’ morphological case. Conversely, P assigns oblique case, but in marked situations P may assign a quirky morphological accusative (German für ‘for’ etc.). As we will see, this pairing of case assigners and NPs rules out a number of somewhat ad hoc analyses of dative alternations in double object constructions.

subsection.heading: 2 The first debate: lexical alternation vs. transformational ‘promotion’
2.1 The dative movement rule
subsection.p: Much early transformational work assumed that the dative alternation resulted from a movement rule, based on the degree of regularity of its operation and the synonymy of the two alternating structures. Versions of the rule generally built the presence of a V into the structural description, since double object constructions exemplify a certain kind of verb complementation. Double object constructions appear only in those phrases which also permit prepositionless (= accusative) direct objects, suggesting that the V and perhaps also the direct object have an important role in licensing a double object construction. 13

Herriman (1995: ch. 2) surveys earlier traditional and generative analyses of indirect objects. A typical treatment (in the introductory text of Akmajian and Heny 1975: 183–186, 220) proposes the following rule of Dative Movement:

(9)
Structural Description:
V NP {to, for} NP
1 2 3 4
Structural Change:
1+4 2 Ø Ø

However, compared with similar early transformational rules such as Passive Formation, the range of conditions on English Dative Movement suggests to many that it cannot be a regular syntactic formation. The dative alternation seems to display to some extent both the features of a transformational alternation and those of a non-productive lexical alternation. Under predominant assumptions in generative thinking, it does not lend itself straightforwardly to either type of analysis. Sentences (10a–b) illustrate one example of a lexical alternation. (Lexical alternations per se are not treated in this study.)

(10)
a. Mary {supplied/donated/*positioned} a weapon to each member.
Mary {supplied/*donated/positioned} each member with a weapon.
b. Carolyn {fed/distributed/*nourished} that cake to my children.
Carolyn {fed/*distributed/nourished} my children with that cake.

As with a lexical alternation, the dative alternation does not apply across the board to all verb phrases meeting the structural description in (9). TO-datives are compatible with certain classes of ‘transfer’ verbs, for example those in (11), and only some of these can undergo the alternation:

(11)
a. Dr. Smith {gave/sent/showed} the library his collection.
b. *Dr. Smith {donated/transferred/showed off} the library his collection.
Similarly, FOR-datives appear with characteristic verbs of preparation and creation, and again, only some of the latter permit the prepositionless variant: 14

(12)
a. Luisa {baked/fashioned/bought} the children some gingerbread houses.
b. *Luisa {invented/devised/dispatched} the children some new toys.

Moreover, while most English verb phrases containing a double NP complement are closely paraphrased by verb phrases containing NP and a to or for phrase, a disparate collection of verbs taking double objects does not permit such paraphrases {e.g. allow, ask, bet, charge, cost, deny, envy, fine, forgive, pardon, spare}:

(13)
a. This watch cost Mary fifty dollars.
The manager denied the students a chance to explain.
b. *This watch cost fifty dollars {to/for} Mary.
*The manager denied a chance to explain {to/for} the students.

Additionally, several authors, such as Green (1974), Oehrle (1976), Pinker (1989), and Jackendoff (1990a), feel that the dative alternations, at least in English, are not really paraphrases. That is, they need not share truth values. Green (1974: 157) claims that learning necessarily occurs for using (14a) felicitously, but not for (14b). Similarly, Pinker (1989) claims that possession must change in (14c) but not in (14d):

(14)
a. Mary taught John linguistics.
b. Mary taught linguistics to John.
c. John threw Bill the book.
d. John threw the book to Bill.

Emonds (1993: 227–228), in contrast, claims that such examples don't actually differ in truth values. 15 Rather, according to Anderson's (1971) study on constant semantic properties of direct objects, truth conditions are preserved in dative alternation pairs as in (1), (2), and (14), while meanings can contrast in pairs of lexical alternations such as (10); one member of some pairs can be true while the other is false.

Other authors have tried to distinguish the two versions of the dative alternation on pragmatic grounds. Erteschik-Shir (1979) claims that the indirect object in double object constructions tends to be definite (for her, “non-dominant”) and Thompson (1995) that it is ‘more topicworthy’. However, such claims seem concerned at most with language use rather than syntax. For example, if a speaker wishes to contest That professor teaches in a sexist way, a perfectly well-formed response can be But nonetheless he always teaches girls the hardest parts of his theories. Here the previously unmentioned indirect object is indefinite and the direct object definite. Syntactically, dative alternations are equally well-formed with definite or indefinite objects in either position.

In the longer perspective, what has finally offset doubts about the synonymy of the English dative alternation and strengthened the hand of transformationalists is a number of carefully argued analyses of double object constructions in a range of non-Indo-European languages. In many such languages, a semantic indirect object alternates freely between a PP and a direct object position; when in the latter position, the verb is regularly inflected as an applicative. Most generativist analyses of applicatives have claimed that this dative alternation is productive. For Chung (1976: 54–55), the only restriction in Indonesian is that “for a handful of verbs whose indirect objects have undergone Dative, the applicative affix may be irregular or covert.” Baker (1988b) contrasts Chiche
a's somewhat sporadically formed locative applicatives with the productivity of its benefactive applicatives. The advancement of indirect to direct object in Tzotzil, a Mayan language, also marked by a regular dative applicative verbal prefix, is not only productive but obligatory: Aissen (1983) concludes that “there are no sentences in which the indirect object has not advanced to direct object.” Moreover she gives empirical arguments that the Tzotzil indirect object is not an ‘initial 2’ of RG (= a base direct object).

While productive relations involving applicative morphemes support a transformational account of dative alternations, they have been studied during a period when construction-specific transformations such as Dative Movement are seen as failing to capture generalizations. Thus, later proposals that the dative alternation derives from movement attempt to subsume it under Move α. These analyses, which will be reviewed in section 4, have tried to derive double object constructions from some combination of language-particular parameters and universal grammatical principles, rather than returning to a specific transformation such as (9).

subsection.heading: 2.2 Lexicalist approaches to double object structures
subsection.p: Some linguists have argued that the English double object structure is not derived by transformation because of its uncertain productivity in that language. Rather, double object structures are directly selected by lexical entries of verbs. The two NPs are then differently interpreted in a semantic component. Oehrle's (1976) dissertation is the first detailed argumentation that dative pairs result from a lexical alternation. Verbs like give and send subcategorize for two sets of complements, NP PP and NP NP. The two sets are related through a ‘lexical redundancy rule’, a less narrowly defined mechanism than movement rules. He proposes that double objects have the ‘flat’ structure in (15), where both NPs are sisters to the verb:

Oehrle additionally argues that certain movement restrictions on dative NPs, which we review in section 3.1, arise from a general constraint on the accessibility of ‘inner’ NPs (those closest to the verb).

The theory of Lexical Functional Grammar (Kaplan and Bresnan 1982) proposes a similar ‘surface’ analysis for double object verbs. Two distinct sets of grammatical functions are assigned to the unified predicate argument structure of Agent, Theme, and Goal:

(16)
a. V (SUBJ) (OBJ2) (OBJ)
b. V (SUBJ) (OBJ) (to OBJ)

These functions then map directly onto surface strings where OBJ2 is Oehrle's ‘inner object’ and the direct object is labelled OBJ. Thus, any systematic pairings of meanings in the double object construction are expressed directly only in predicate argument structures. As for any syntactic correspondences, the LFG system also “captures the systematic connection between NP–NP and NP-to-NP constructions by means of a lexical redundancy rule” (Kaplan and Bresnan 1982: 180).

Although Green's (1974) framework includes transformational relations, she bases her analysis of indirect objects rather on the semantic properties of relevant verbs. She groups verbs that license Dative Movement into different semantic classes, and relates these classes to different underlying structures, associating several verbs with the base structure (15) rather than a structure including a PP. For example, pass and take are in the ‘bring’ category, feed is in the ‘give’ category, buy and save in the ‘selection’ group, and so on. She concludes that ‘Dative Movement’ should actually be divided into a series of interrelated processes that relate double object constructions and NP–PP sequences in either direction – from NP PP to NP NP or from NP NP to NP PP – according to those combinations of semantic features available for the verb in question. This approach is actually reminiscent of Harris's (1957) notion of transformational relations between sets of surface paradigms.

Pinker (1989) formulates a theory of lexicosemantic representation that attempts to make the semantic characteristics of ‘dativizable’ verbs more precise. His main concern is how children are able to learn the dative alternation without access to negative evidence. That is, the child must learn without being told which verbs are unavailable for the double object construction. For example, how does the learner realize that give is acceptable in this context, but donate is (usually) not, although the two verbs have very similar meanings? (For a full discussion of this issue, see Pinker 1989: ch. 1.)

Pinker proposes a ‘Grammatically Relevant Subsystem’ hypothesis, arguing that “there is a set of semantic elements and relations that is much smaller than the set of cognitively available and culturally salient distinctions, and verb meanings are organized around them” (Pinker 1989: 166). Linguistic processes, including lexical alternations, are sensitive only to members of this set. He then develops a set of relevant verbal features and uses linking rules to map certain groupings of features onto certain syntactic structures. These features are detailed enough to distinguish between dativizable verbs and similar verbs that do not display the dative alternation. (See Pinker 1989: ch. 5.) Although Pinker's analysis is lexicalist in the sense that he assumes without argument that ‘Dative Movement’ is a lexical alternation, nothing in his theory precludes applying it to a transformational theory of datives. In fact, it might serve to weaken one of the main arguments against Dative Movement, that its application is not predictable.

Jackendoff (1990a) is another theorist who believes, like Oehrle, that a lack of full productivity in the dative alternation supports a purely lexical account of double objects. He reserves transformations for more transparently regular alternations such as passive. He elaborates on some of Green's ideas for verb classes, claiming that the semantic facts of double objects and their verbs militate against a transformational analysis, at least for English. For Jackendoff, generalizations about theta-roles do not explain the difference between verbs that allow double objects and those that do not. Unlike Pinker, he finds no plausible contrast between the roles assigned by give and donate, which both appear to assign ‘beneficiary’ and ‘goal’ roles to their complements. He feels rather that the inherent meanings of verbs determine whether there is a dative alternation.
For example, verbs of creation or preparation such as sing or bake allow double objects, while benefactive NPs with other verbs such as copy or eat occur only in for-phrases:

(17)
a. Enrico {sang/copied} an aria for Luisa.
b. Enrico {sang/*copied} Luisa an aria.
c. Susan {baked/ate} some vegetables for her mother.
d. Susan {baked/*ate} her mother some vegetables.

But Jackendoff's analysis of this paradigm actually undermines his argument that dative alternations are lexical. He suggests that creation/preparation verbs take a for-phrase complement, whereas for-phrases with verbs like eat and copy are adjuncts. But if so, Move α cannot ‘lower’ an adjunct, presumably base-generated outside V1, into direct object position. A transformational account therefore seems to explain precisely the contrast Jackendoff brings to bear against it. 16

Along similar lines, Jackendoff (1990a: 449) favors a lexicalist account for a generalization of Pinker (1989), whereby motion verbs that “imply influence of the Agent continuing throughout the Theme's trajectory” do not appear with double objects:

(18)
a. He {dragged/moved/pushed} the material to Bill.
*He {dragged/moved/pushed} Bill the material.
b. He {dropped/kicked/threw} the material to Bill.
He {dropped/kicked/threw} Bill the material.

An adequate analysis should probably relate this distinction to whether the P indicates an actual spatial trajectory, as in (18a), or whether it simply introduces a third NP argument, as in (18b). We return to this distinction in section 2.5.

Lexical explanations for the dative alternation among Chomskyan theorists received a theory-internal boost in 1981. Chomsky's Lectures on Government and Binding does not argue against a movement derivation for double objects. However, his Projection Principle, a central tenet of Government-Binding theory, requires that the argument structure and thematic roles of complement phrases remain constant throughout a derivation. As it is used in that work, this principle rules out the possibility of a surface structure configuration like (19a) (where the complement phrase consists of two NPs) being transformationally derived from a deep structure (19b) (where the complement phrase consists of an NP and a PP):

Thus, we understand why Czepluch (1982: 1) introduces a contemporaneous discussion of the dative alternation with the comment: “Nowadays it is widely held that the alternation between the prepositional IO and the prepositionless IO represents a lexical rather than a transformational relationship.”

subsection.heading: 2.3 Transformationalist objections to lexicalist approaches
subsection.p: Generativists (e.g., Czepluch 1982: note 5) could nonetheless see that assuming Oehrle's (20) as the deep structure for double objects creates many problems for Government-Binding theory:
We enumerate five such problems with flat double object structures here:

(i) A flat deep structure for double objects precludes any straightforward syntactic account of the synonymous pairs in the dative alternation, including the pairings in the fairly transparent productive applicative systems of the Bantu languages, Indonesian, etc. 17

(ii) A simple and hence optimal case theory states that case assigners (such as V and P) assign exactly one grammatical case to a single, adjacent NP (cf. Pesetsky 1995: 124). This is our Structure-Dependent Case theory in (8). In a flat structure, the assignment of case to the second NP of the double object construction in (20) becomes problematic. Chomsky (1981: ch. 3) assumes that the V in this situation assigns an additional ‘inherent Case’ to one of the objects and the usual structural case to the other. Thus one or the other type of case assignment applies over an adjacent NP only in this exceptional instance. As explained in a cross-linguistic study of passives (Åfarli 1992: section 3.1), such double assignment of case undercuts attempts at coherently characterizing ‘case-absorption’ in passives.

(iii) Work on double object applicative constructions in non-Indo-European languages, first in the framework of Relational Grammar (Chung 1976; Kimenyi 1980; Aissen 1983) and later in Government-Binding under the impetus of Marantz (1984) and Baker (1985a, 1988a), revealed many syntactic properties which demonstrate that prepositionless indirect objects function cross-linguistically as surface direct objects, while the deep direct objects they occur with do not. An additional paradigm using particles (Emonds 1972a) supports the same conclusion for English. This body of work taken together (see section 3.2) argues that the indirect object must be ‘promoted’ (using Relational Grammar terms) from a deep status of an ‘initial 3’ (a deep oblique complement) to a ‘final 2’ (a surface direct object) in the course of a derivation. Flat deep structures obscure this ‘promotion’.

(iv) Whether or not one embeds a flat deep structure (20) into the Government-Binding framework, any explanation of the syntactic restrictions on double object constructions (discussed in section 3.2) based on some kind of structural ‘inaccessibility’ of an inner NP is too powerful. It incorrectly predicts that indirect object NPs cannot be passivized; see note 1. Whitney (1982, 1983) and Czepluch (1982) discuss in more detail the inadequacy of the structure (20) as a basis for explaining the grammatical relations and syntactic properties of double object constructions.

(v) The important and influential squib of Barss and Lasnik (1986) shows that several considerations based on binding of anaphors, weak crossover, quantifier-variable pairings, superiority, and negative polarity – the very cornerstones of Government-Binding theory – require that the indirect object in a double object construction, for example in (1b), (2b), and (14a, c), asymmetrically c-command the direct object to its right. (Cf. also Larson 1988b; Pesetsky 1995: 125–126.) As this influential piece is transparently written, easily accessible, and mercifully brief, we will not summarize it further, but simply accept their preliminary conclusion as a basis for further discussion: “The problem now is to determine how it is that the first NP in a double-object VP asymmetrically c-commands the second NP, and this requires discussion of the phrase structure of these VPs” (Barss and Lasnik 1986: 350). 18

A final logical weakness of lexicalist accounts of datives is the nature of their argument that, since non-alternating double objects (double object sentences without a to- or for-phrase paraphrase) occur anyway, a rule of dative movement is redundant. This reasoning is curious, since prosaic sentences resembling passive transforms (John was killed by the riverside) are never taken to argue for the redundancy of the passive transformation. 19

Perhaps what is lacking from the lexicalist perspective is the ability to imagine a plausible derivation for these non-alternating sentences. Suppose that a double object verb such as cost or deny is lexically specified for two NP complements, as in This watch cost Mary fifty dollars. An obvious consequence of an optimal case theory such as (8) is that a V cannot have two object NP sisters, so that the most economical base structure that satisfies such a lexical specification is (21):
(21) This watch cost NP [PP [P Ø] NP]

Herriman (1995: 204), citing several traditional grammarians, observes that the second complements of many non-alternating double objects are indeed akin to “NP adverbials.” They are thus possibly PPs whose P is idiomatically zeroed either optionally (envy, forgive) or obligatorily (fine, spare). Other verbs with non-alternating double objects may fall under one of the analyses in section 2.5.
We conclude that non-alternating double objects, as in (13), do not bear on the issue of whether English or any other language exhibits transformational raising of indirect to direct objects.

subsection.heading: 2.4 Government-Binding attempts to save a lexicalist analysis
subsection.p: The tension resulting from the requirements of Government-Binding theory 20 and the need for a cross-linguistically convincing analysis for double objects stimulated a “datives industry” throughout the 1980s and early 1990s. Some linguists first attempted to reconcile a theory of base-generated double objects with Chomsky's Case theory by building in covert syntactic structure. In particular, Czepluch (1982) and Kayne (1984b) analyze the indirect object NP as a ‘covert’ PP with a P that remains empty throughout the derivation, as in (22). In both analyses, the direct object is case-marked by the verb, although not under the adjacency to V0 required by Stowell (1981):

Czepluch (1982) proposes that ordering of the PP before the NP in (22) is determined by the requirements of case assignment and Chomsky's Empty Category Principle, which forces the dummy P to be properly governed. The empty P attaches to the verb through Reanalysis, allowing the verb to indirectly transmit case to the indirect object NP.

For Kayne (1984b: 195–196), “an empty preposition cannot be the source of Case,” but can “transmit to its object an objective case received by percolation only if prepositions in that language normally assign objective case. Then objective case transmission by Pe is available in English, but not in French.” Kayne's proposal is then that P assigns case differently in the two languages, although neither language has overt case morphology outside the pronoun system. 21 This treatment of the dative also “leads one to conclude that the [dative passive] is an instance of preposition stranding, . . . except that the stranded preposition is empty” (1984b: 196).

While we share with Zhang some uncertainty over exactly what Kayne and also Larson (1988b) actually imply in this regard, we agree that “under one possible interpretation, Kayne's and Larson's theory makes the following claim: Languages that do not permit P-stranding also do not permit Dative Shift” (Zhang 1990). Hoekstra (1995: 122) makes this explicit: “the English pattern of indirect object passivization is limited to languages allowing preposition stranding.” Zhang's squib shows that Chinese contradicts any such claim, as do Indonesian and other non-Indo-European languages with dative applicatives. As observed in Van Riemsdijk (1978a), P-stranding is rare and probably limited to a subset of Germanic languages; hence it cannot be a precondition of a dative alternation.

Stowell (1981) analyzes the dative alternation in terms of movement, but upon closer inspection it is more a lexicalist than a ‘Move α’ solution. In his view, indirect object NPs incorporate into the verb (V0) by means of a ‘word formation rule’, one which creates words of unlimited complexity, such as the bold sequence in The girl sent the man who had won huge sums of money at Monte Carlo flowers. The complex verb assigns case to the direct object NP and, rather problematically, the prepositionless indirect object also receives or ‘absorbs’ case from the adjacent verb. An indirect object is thus realized either as a lexical NP or an empty NP co-indexed with the incorporated NP, as in (23):
If a lexical indirect object NP is realized outside V0, the P to is inserted adjacent to it as its case-assigner.

Stowell's solution to the non-productivity issue incorporates aspects of earlier lexicalist semantic proposals. He notes that obligatory double object verbs such as cost indicate a kind of possession of the direct object by the indirect. Presumably, the indirect object has a Possessor theta-role in these cases, but not the role of Goal. On the other hand, some indirect object NPs receive the role of Goal but not that of Possessor, as exemplified in David sent a package to England. Stowell proposes to attribute the dative alternation to an indirect object having the double role of Goal/Possessor (or Goal/Beneficiary in the case of FOR-datives). When a V allows a dual interpretation, the indirect object NP may incorporate into the V or not. If V assigns only the Possessor role, NP must incorporate; if V assigns only the role of Goal, incorporation is disallowed.

For Stowell, indirect objects receive theta-roles differently according to their structural position after Dative Movement. That is, if Possessor is something like a ‘principal’ theta-role, the NP must be inside V0, while a Goal as a principal theta-role is incompatible with such an NP. However one formalizes this relation between word formation and theta-roles, it is the output of his Dative Movement that is playing the classical role of deep structure. That is, (23) represents the level relevant for theta-role interpretation, which is in turn input to a transformational derivation. But any rule that applies prior to deep structure in a Government-Binding framework is not a transformation but a lexical relation. Finally, then, Stowell's is a lexicalist solution.
Hellan (1991b) proposes the following covert structure to solve the case-marking problem (ii) of section 2.3. He adopts a right-branching base structure, as shown in (24):

The verb marks the topmost NP-DO for case, in accordance with Stowell's (1981) adjacency requirement. Case-marking then percolates down to the lower NP-DO. The indirect object is inherently case-marked by virtue of its position in the structure, similar to Chomsky's (1981) proposal for how an English possessive NP receives its case. Like the ‘small clause’ analyses we review later, one can say that Hellan's (24) straightforwardly expresses Stowell's idea that the indirect object ‘possesses’ the direct object in the double object construction. On the other hand, the notion of case being assigned without a case assigner contravenes the original concept of abstract case, which pairs case assigners with case-marked NPs. Moreover, as will be seen in section 4.4, the existence of a single constituent uniting both double objects is problematic.

The above four Government-Binding variants of base-generated double objects (Czepluch, Hellan, Kayne 1984b, and Stowell) do not provide an appropriate underlying structure for the asymmetrical c-command required by Barss and Lasnik (1986), or for explaining the derived direct object properties (iii) and (iv) of section 2.3. In addition, beyond one or two considerations that each author brings up in support of his idea, their modifications away from an optimal version of case theory, where case assigners assign only one kind of case to a single sister NP along the lines of Structure-Dependent Case (8), don't simplify or explain other areas of grammar.

Our conclusion is that, taken together, the arguments (i)–(v) against flat structures enumerated in section 2.3 settle the first debate. Lexicalist analyses, especially in the Government-Binding framework, have not solved the double case problem (ii). They do not address the compelling cross-linguistic regularities of applicative constructions (iii), summarized below in section 3.2. And they fail to provide the badly needed asymmetric c-command of the deep direct object by the bare indirect object (v). We thus take the position that a double object construction results from transformationally promoting to direct object a deep indirect object of a P, whose untransformed English spell-out is a to or for phrase. The still debated nature of this transformational process will occupy us in section 4.

subsection.heading: 2.5 Solving non-productivity
subsection.p: The transformationalist accounts of productive non-Indo-European dative and benefactive applicative constructions have emboldened advocates of dative movement, but a more satisfactory account of its non-productivity in English is still needed. Some variant of Pesetsky's (1995: section 5.1.3) proposal to extend a type of applicative suffix to English (and perhaps other Germanic languages) may solve this problem.

Suppose that English verbs in either TO-dative or FOR-dative alternations occur with a null affix of derivational morphology as in either (25a) or (25b). We leave aside discussion of its features and its role in licensing double objects until section 3.4. For the moment, we take this derivational formation to be ‘right-hand headed’ in the sense of Williams (1981b), as in either (25a) or (25b), and we assume that this null affix shares a feature PATH with the directional P that it appears to replace:

Under this analysis, English now conforms to a cross-linguistic generalization, which Den Dikken (1995c: ch. 5) refers to as the “systematic homophony of so-called applicative and causative affixes.” He fully illustrates this phenomenon, based on parallel verb affixations in Indonesian, Nahuatl (Tuggy 1987), and Sanuma (Borgman 1989). Using Pesetsky's zero morpheme, we can say that English applicatives and English causatives for many base adjectives are also homophonous: they share a (non-productive) zero affix. 22

On one level, this proposal just displaces the problem of non-productivity into the lexicon, but this is where both morpheme lists and null morphs are known to play a role (Pesetsky 1995: 128–129). For example, it allows for natural expression of a generalization about word formation that must haunt even the most devoted partisans of lexical unpredictability: namely, general classes of ‘short’ verbs in English enter into dative alternations productively.

In this regard, Fraser's (1974: 13–15) discussion of which verbs combine with postverbal particles is pertinent, for the same class of English verbs productively exhibits TO-dative and FOR-dative alternations. “Surprisingly enough, it is the phonological shape of a verb that determines to a large extent whether or not it can combine with a particle. . . . the majority of verbs occurring with particles are monosyllabic and the remainder are made up primarily of bi-syllabic words which are initially stressed.” The English lexicon must thus contain the following restriction on ‘null applicatives’:

(26)
Restricted style:
Verb stems whose only stress is initial combine productively with a null applicative affix.23

Once (26) is properly expressed as derivational morphology, relatively few double object verbs have to be listed separately as appearing either optionally or obligatorily with the null applicative affix. For the TO-dative alternation, the following verbs with some non-initial stress are listed in Herriman (1995: 61, 104): accord, administer, advance, afford, allocate, allot, allow, apportion, assign, assure, award, begrudge, bequeath, concede, deliver, deny, extend, forbid, permit, prohibit, recommend, refund, refuse, reimburse, remit, repay, return, telegraph, telephone, and vouchsafe. For the FOR-dative she lists (1995: 124, 146) design, embroider, ensure, furnish, guarantee, occasion, prepare, prescribe, procure, provide, purchase, reserve, and secure. However, most of these ‘exceptions’ can be analyzed as containing a prefix and an initially stressed stem. 24

In standard American speech, verbs that carry secondary or non-initial stress are usually incompatible with a dative alternation. However, (26) may be relaxed to a style (27) in which any singly stressed English verb can take double objects. This accounts for examples like the following, although they are still excluded in the restricted style: We delivered Mary the package; Bill embroidered her a blouse:

(27)
Relaxed style:
Verb stems lacking secondary stress combine productively with a null applicative affix.

This change of style drastically shortens Herriman's list of exceptional double object verbs. In the other direction, some of the non-alternating double object verbs discussed in section 2.3 (e.g., ask, bet, charge, cost, deny) may be lexically listed as obligatorily requiring the null applicative affix; little would seem to turn on this.

Gropen et al. (1989: 243–245) list some verb classes that don't occur with double NPs even though they satisfy (26). Two types are “manner of speaking” verbs (scream, whisper, yell) and verbs of continuously caused motion (drag, move, push), exemplified in (18) in section 2.2. Indirect objects of such verbs are always expressed in to-phrases. In these cases, following Larson (1988b: section 5), it may well be that the P's independent theta-role assigning content causes it to be present throughout the derivation. In the terms of Emonds (1993), reviewed here in section 4.5, such Ps are lexicalized in deep structure, which blocks their object NP from advancing to direct object. Pesetsky (1995) and Den Dikken (1995c) propose a similar account in terms of a lexical P that assigns a theta-role characterized by “continuous imparting of force.” As a reviewer notes, perhaps the term ‘indirect object’ is simply not appropriate for objects of these contentful Ps.

subsection.heading: 3 An emerging consensus: transformational raising of the indirect object to direct object position
3.1.1 The Restriction on A′-extraction
subsection.p: In section 2.4, we concluded that a double object construction results from transformationally promoting to direct object a deep indirect object of a P, whose untransformed English spell-out is to or for. An anti-transformationalist counter might claim that the apparently ‘promoted’ italicized objects in (1b−2b) are simply parallel to the italicized deep objects with ‘Goal’ theta-roles in (28b):
(1) b. Mary sent each family member a present.
(2) b. Carolyn baked my children that cake.

(28)
a. Mary provided a present to each family member.
Carolyn supplied that material to my children.
b. Mary provided each family member with a present.
Carolyn supplied my children with that material.

In addition to the telling semantic arguments of Anderson (1971) against this view, a cross-linguistic syntactic property also suggests that the surface objects in (1b−2b) have a different syntactic status from those in (28b). Generally, Goal direct objects can move freely, exactly like other direct objects, to any peripheral position (e.g., by wh-fronting or rightward Complex NP Shift). However:

(29)
Restriction on A′-extraction:
Movement of a ‘promoted’ indirect object NP unmarked by a P or dative case to a non-argument position is ungrammatical.
This restriction on what Government and Binding calls ‘A′-movements’ holds for both Goals (to-datives) and Beneficiaries (for-datives): 25

(30)
a. ??Which sisteri shall we send ti a present?
??Whoi did Carolyn bake ti that cake?
b. *This is the friendi (that) {Mary sent ti a present/Carolyn baked ti that cake}.
c. *Kidsi are always easy to {tell ti a story/buy ti presents}.
d. *Charlie {sent ti a book/baked ti that cake} [the girl who lives next door]i.

For English, this restriction on wh-movement is first noted in Fillmore (1965). Ross (1986) observes that indirect objects without P cannot undergo rightward Complex NP Shift (30d) either. Further examples of (29) are presented and discussed in Oehrle (1976), Ziv and Sheintuch (1979), Hornstein and Weinberg (1981), Whitney (1982, 1983), Czepluch (1982), Barss and Lasnik (1986), Baker (1988a: section 5.4), and Hellan (1991b).

As Whitney (1982, 1984) observes for English, the restriction (29) generalizes to all Government and Binding ‘A′-movements’, that is, movements to non-argument positions, whether to the left or right, as in (30d). 26 This bi-directionality in itself excludes any account of (29) that depends on a left–right asymmetry, such as many theories of parsing and some syntactic theories. These movement restrictions apply even though the dative NP behaves like a direct object in other ways (see section 3.2) and is in a position (next to the verb) in which a base-generated direct object would be movable.

This descriptive generalization is no artifact of English. It holds cross-linguistically for applicative languages such as Chiche
a (31) and Chamorro (32) (data reproduced from Baker 1988a: 291–292): 27

(31)
a. Atsikana a-na-perek-er-a mfumu chitseko.
girl SP-PAST-hand-APPL-ASP chief door
‘The girl handed the chief the door.’
b. *Iyi ndi mfumu imene ndi-na-nen-a kuti atsikana a-na-perek-er-a chitseko
This is chief which 1sS-PAST-say-ASP that girl SP-PAST-hand-APPL-ASP door
‘This is the chief which I said that the girl handed the door.’

(32)
a. Hu tugi’-i i che’lu-hu ni kätta.
1sS-write-APPL the sibling-my OBL letter
‘I wrote my brother the letter.’
b. *Hayi t-in-igi’-i-n-ñiha ni kätta?
who NOM-write-APPL-LK-their OBL letter
‘Who did they write the letter (to)?’
(31b) contrasts with the permitted relativization of an ordinary direct object (Baker 1988a: 289):

(33)
Iyi ndi mfumu imene ndi-ku-ganiz-a kuti a-na-on-a.
this is chief which 1sS-PRES-think-ASP that 3sS-PAST-see-ASP
‘This is the chief that I think she saw.’

Before reviewing how authors have treated restriction (29) theoretically, it is important to appreciate that this kind of syntactic property strongly suggests that a promoted Goal phrase, even though it has the position and many other properties of a direct object, is not simply that. Even without a fully satisfactory account of the cross-linguistic paradigm (29), a promotion analysis at least distinguishes between (1–2) and (28b). Simply considering double object constructions to be base-generated provides no reason at all to expect different behavior under A′-movement.

subsection.heading: 3.1.2 Accounts of the Restriction on A′-extraction
subsection.p:
Oehrle's (1976) base analysis includes the statement that inner NPs, that is, those followed by a direct object, are inaccessible to movement rules, but this basically only rephrases the problem posed by restriction (29). Moreover, Baker (1988a: 295) points out that explanations based on the inaccessibility of an inner NP (as defined by the simultaneous presence of an ‘outer NP’) encounter a further difficulty. In Chiche
a and Chamorro, morphologically identifiable applicatives with promoted oblique NPs can be formed with certain classes of intransitive verbs. Extraction of the applied object in these cases is just as bad as extraction of the inner object of a transitive verb. Accounts of (29) that depend on the presence of two NPs, rather than on the derivational status of the promoted NP, are thus inadequate.

Stowell's (1981) solution for the Restriction on A′-extraction (29) is somewhat more attractive. Recall that in his analysis (23), a bare English indirect object (of whatever length) is incorporated under the V by a ‘word formation rule’. It then follows that the inner NP cannot be further moved, as syntactic rules never apply to parts of words. Larson (1988a) also invokes some type of inaccessibility restriction based on a verb forming a deep constituent with an indirect object. 28 Both Stowell and Larson circumvent the problem of the bare dative NPs’ seeming ability to move (only) to A-positions by claiming that ‘dative passives’ (34) involve movement from an outer, non-promoted position directly to the subject position. Since the deep indirect objects then receive case after passivization, there is no need for an oblique to or for with a trace tk:

(34)
Wek might be given a book tk.
A womank was offered the job tk.
The guestsk were finally fixed an appropriate lunch tk.

Once English dative passives are not derived directly from double object constructions, however, an important generalization is lost. Early generative analyses observed that English verbs which do not permit prepositionless double objects prohibit dative passives as well:

(35)
*Our club might be {distributed/donated/suggested} some books.
*A woman was {demonstrated/outlined/revealed} the procedure.
*The guests were finally {concocted/designed/reordered} an appropriate lunch.

That is, dative passives appear to derive, in English at least, from double object constructions. Hoekstra (1995: section 3) provides two further arguments against passivizing indirect objects in their base position. Along the same lines, Romance languages lack dative passives because they lack bare double objects. Thus, the following descriptive generalization encompasses both English and Romance:

(36)
Dative passive Restriction:
Passivization of indirect objects (unmarked by any dative case) results from moving NPs already promoted to direct object.
The Stowell and Larson accounts of dative passives contravene (36) and thus fail to predict data such as (35) naturally.

Czepluch (1982) takes a different approach to the restriction in (29). As seen in section 2.4, he analyzes bare datives in terms of a base-generated PP headed by an empty P. He rules out extraction of the bare dative NP through a constraint on movement out of empty-headed phrases, which would leave a presumably unacceptable ‘layered trace’ under a PP. In order to nonetheless allow dative passives, Czepluch must extend case theory so that these layered traces are unacceptable only under the conditions of A′-movement. That is, a sentence like *Who did John give the book? is ruled out because the trace of who cannot be either directly or indirectly case-marked.

Den Dikken (1995c: section 4.2) provides a somewhat similar account of (29) that also involves the structure of a PP. Summarizing relevant data from a range of authors, he concludes that only “short” (clause-bound) wh-movement of promoted IOs can be grammatical, as in (30a), and this only in some languages, such as Dutch, Norwegian, and certain dialects of English. For these systems with grammatical “short” overt wh-movement of indirect objects, i.e., which seems to contravene (29), Den Dikken argues that an entire PP headed by an empty dative-assigning P is fronted. 29 In contrast, he claims that many A′-extractions, including at least those in (30b–c), involve Empty Operator Movement or more generally simple movement of an NP, and these are always excluded (1995: 188). Our formulation of (29) does not require P to be overt, and hence countenances Den Dikken's analysis or others which permit a fronting of an empty-headed PP.

Baker (1988a: 299) proposes a different refinement of Czepluch's approach, which he calls the Non-Oblique Trace Filter. This filter blocks any trace of an A′-operator lacking oblique case if its non-verbal governor incorporates into a higher verb. By stipulating the presence of an operator in the filter, he automatically exempts passive traces from it while still blocking A′-movements, or in other words the restriction stated as (29). It is doubtful whether this ad hoc device works empirically, since it also appears to wrongly rule out A′-movement of a passivized bare indirect object, which is cross-linguistically permitted (Alsina and Mchombo 1990: section 2).

Hellan (1991b) illustrates (29) for Mainland Scandinavian, arguing that the trace of an A′-movement of a bare indirect object is ill-formed, rather than movement itself. In his structure (24) for double objects, the verb governs just the direct object; the bare indirect object is licensed and receives a theta-role only by virtue of its structural position (akin to a possessive NP). Moreover, he claims that such lexical NPs do not need to receive an abstract case, whereas traces of wh-movement uniformly do require case. Hence, those NPs licensed by virtue of their structural position, and not by a lexical licenser, are precisely those which cannot undergo A′-movement (29). A virtue of this proposal is that it can account for why possessive NPs in English, for example, are not available for A′-movement either. However, it must be observed that extracting possessive NPs (the Left Branch Constraint of Ross 1986) is significantly less acceptable than violating (29).

Whitney (1982, 1983) proposes an account of (29) that does not require extending case theory or special restrictions on movement of the inner NP. Like Czepluch and Baker, she assumes that indirect objects are generated under a PP. They then move to their surface position next to the verb, leaving a trace in the usual way:

All further movements to an A′-position, including Complex NP Shift and other A′-movements (Whitney 1983, 1984), leave a trace that serves as a variable in LF. Further movement of indirect objects is then blocked by Chomsky's (1982: 31) principle that a variable “must be A-free in the domain of the operator that binds it.” The variable in the position of IOk is under the first branching node V′ over the original indirect object trace, therefore not A-free. 30

This analysis correctly predicts that wh-movement, Complex NP Shift, and other movements of bare indirect objects to A′-positions are ruled out, while movements to an A-position, like passive, are acceptable. It also distinguishes base-generated NPs next to the verb, which are extractable, from indirect objects that have been promoted to direct object position, which are not.

Whatever the ultimate fate of these competing proposals for explaining the restriction (29), this robust cross-linguistic paradigm itself strongly suggests that bare indirect objects are not generated in the base as direct objects but rather move to their surface position. The restriction on their further movement, which base-generated direct objects are not subject to, can be satisfactorily accounted for only if their transformational history is distinct from that of direct objects.

subsection.heading: 3.1.3 Scope Freezing: confirmation of indirect object promotion
subsection.p: Some double object studies whose structural proposals we will review in section 4, e.g., Aoun and Li (1989) and Larson (1990), have brought out a property of double objects that confirms their status as a derived, non-base construction. In English at least, many quantified NP arguments may optionally take ‘wide scope’ over a higher one in base constructions:

(38)
a. Two new topics might reinvigorate every girl in the class.
b. He assigned two new topics to every girl in the class.
c. It seemed to every girl in the class that two new topics were needed.

In (38a–b), the topics may vary as a function of the girls, i.e., the lower bold NPs may take wide scope over the higher italic NPs. In the other interpretation, the topics are fixed independent of every girl (i.e., the higher italic NPs take wide scope). Similarly in (38c), the lower bold NP may take either wide scope (the topics are fixed) or narrow scope (the topics vary with the girls).

But as Aoun and Li (1989, 1993b) point out, a prepositionless indirect object as in (39) seems to tolerate only wide scope. That is, (39) does not typically mean that every girl had the same topics. Rather, the girl is fixed first (wide scope) and then the topics:
(39) He assigned every girl in the class two new topics.

What is of interest in this regard is that wide-scope readings of the higher italic NPs are also strongly favoured in structures derived by subject raising (40a), passive (40b), and, as pointed out by a reviewer, locative inversion (40c):

(40)
a. Two new topics seemed to every girl to be unfair.
b. Every girl in the class might be reinvigorated by two new topics.
c. On two big billboards were (painted) every party's slogans.

The property illustrated in (39)–(40) is called ‘Scope Freezing’. A plausible initial description of what is at stake involves movements into argument positions, which in a range of cases are apparently subject to (41):

(41)
English Scope Freezing:
NPs moved into A-positions must take wide scope over NPs that they c-command.

We are often somewhat sceptical of the relevant acceptability judgments, and consequently find it difficult to use Scope Freezing to evaluate the merits of the rather complex structures and derivations proposed by various authors. What seems clearer and actually more to the point for our purposes is the fact that this phenomenon pretty clearly groups together promoted prepositionless indirect objects with other ‘moved NPs’ such as those raised to SPEC(IP) in (40). Thus, while it is easy to interpret the base-generated example He talked with every girl in the class about two new topics with wide scope on topics (there are only two), a parallel interpretation of (39) seems at best forced and unnatural.

From this perspective, whatever its ultimate structural analysis, it is plausible to conclude that Scope Freezing (41) constitutes a second diagnostic for the derived rather than base-generated status of bare indirect object NPs.

subsection.heading: 3.2 Direct object properties of promoted indirect objects (Relational Grammar 3 → 2)
subsection.p: Section 3.1.1 has highlighted an important syntactic property (29) of prepositionless indirect objects that ‘betrays their origins’: these objects differ from direct objects in resisting A′-movements. Deep direct objects with a Goal role are not subject to this restriction: What did you spray with paint? Who did you approach on the street? Provided promoted indirect objects leave a trace of some sort, an account of (29) in terms of a general condition on variable binding is in principle available.

A second restriction on promoted indirect objects is ‘Scope Freezing’, i.e., their inability to house (English) quantifiers with narrow scope, as discussed in section 3.1.3. Finally, a third restriction, observed in Baker (1988a: 278–279, 1988b), is that the head indirect object noun in benefactive applicatives cannot ‘incorporate’ into a governing verb (in contrast to a deep direct object noun). We thus have three independent reasons to believe that bare indirect objects are not simply structural deep objects with Goal theta-roles, but are somehow transformationally derived.

With respect to most other properties, however, dative shifted NPs behave like direct objects, whether or not a language has an overt applicative affix. In Relational Grammar (RG) studies such as Perlmutter and Postal (1983b), this change is described as ‘3 to 2 advancement’, where 2 indicates a direct object. As a result of advancement, a deep or initial indirect object behaves like a direct object with respect to a whole battery of syntactic and morphological diagnostics for direct objects. A side effect of this advancement is that a deep or initial direct object NP is demoted to what RG calls ‘chômeur’ status. That is, a chômeur NP fails a number of these same diagnostic tests for surface direct object status.

In many languages with productive dative alternations, an overt ‘applicative’ verbal affix accompanies the advancement to direct object. Marantz (1982) proposes that this situation is typical: when verbs have supplementary overt morphology corresponding to an oblique argument NP, that NP and not the usual direct object behaves like a surface direct object. Baker (1988a: section 5.3.1) refers to this remarkable cross-linguistic pattern as Marantz's Generalization. However, as we see below, advancement is not invariably accompanied by an overt applicative suffix.

subsection.heading: 3.2.1 Indonesian
subsection.p: Chung (1976) is a thorough RG study of indirect objects in Indonesian (= Bahasa Indonesia), whose basic word order is S-V-O-(PP). “Dative permutes a direct object with an indirect object or benefactive, and deprives the indirect object/benefactive of its preposition. . . . Some form of the benefactive suffix . . . is typically added to the verb” (1976: 41). She emphasizes that P is omitted if and only if “the IO is moved between the DO and the verb,” exactly as specified in the early transformational rule (9) for English:

(5)
a. Ali mem-beli telefisi untuk ibu-nja.
Ali TRN-buy television for mother-his
‘Ali bought a television for his mother.’
b. Ali mem-beli-kan ibu-nja telefisi.
Ali TRN-buy-APPL mother-his television
‘Ali bought his mother a television.’

Chung then goes on to provide extensive and convincing arguments that an indirect object promoted by Dative behaves as a direct object in Indonesian. “The IO can, for instance, be passivized. . . . It can be replaced by the true reflexive, diri ‘self’. . . . It can undergo Object Preposing, if the subject of the sentence is a pronoun [the normal condition on this rule]. . . . And the original IO is subject to the major [deletion] strategy, with jang, for Relative Clause Formation . . . In contrast, [for any of these diagnostics] the underlying DO no longer behaves like a direct object after Dative has applied” (1976: 58–60).

subsection.heading: 3.2.2 Kinyarwanda
subsection.p: Kimenyi's (1980) analysis of Kinyarwanda advancement is another detailed RG study of double objects. We have used the succinct summary of this work in Poser (1982).

Kimenyi finds evidence for several transformational alternations of complement phrases in the language, and the various rules promoting oblique objects introduce applicative inflections on the verb. One of these rules promotes indirect objects to direct object status. His study enumerates an impressive number of corresponding operations distinguishing Kinyarwanda direct from oblique objects, which he refers to under the rubrics of Passive, Stativization, Object–Subject Reversal, Pronoun Incorporation, Reflexivization, Clefting, Pseudo-Clefting, Exclusive Insertion, and Existential Insertion. Using the same logic as Chung's study, he then shows that Kinyarwanda prepositionless indirect objects invariably act like direct objects with respect to these operations.

subsection.heading: 3.2.3 Tzotzil
subsection.p: Aissen's (1983) RG study of indirect objects in Tzotzil shows that arguments for advancement to direct object can be constructed even in the absence of a dative alternation. She specifically couches her analysis in terms of derivations: “While my conception of sentence structure follows that of relational grammar in its essentials, I assume that these levels of relational structure do constitute a derivation, roughly in the spirit of transformational grammar” (1983: 274).

A special characteristic of Tzotzil is that its lexicon lacks P morphemes whereby indirect objects can surface in PPs. “Two facts about Tzotzil obscure the existence of Indirect Object Advancement. First is the fact that [42] is the only way to say ‘I sold pigs to Sun’. . . . Second, čitom ‘pig’ in [42] is, it will be claimed, the initial direct object, but not final direct object, this relation being held by li Sune. Citom is a final direct object chômeur” (1983: 272–273):

(42)
I-h-čon-be čitom li Sune.
ASP-ERG1-sell-APPL pig the Sun
‘I sold the pigs to Sun.’

Aissen makes the case for advancement by isolating three tests for direct objecthood: direct objects agree with a verb in person and animate number (43a), and they are the only passivizable complements:

(43)
a. Mi č-a-mah-on?
Q ASP-ERG2-hit-ABS1
‘Are you going to hit me?’
b. Mi mu š-a-čon-b-on l-a-čitome?
Q-NEG ASP-ERG2-sell-APPL-ABS1 the-your-pig
‘Won't you sell me your pigs?’

She observes that in the double object construction “the verb agrees in person with the indirect object and not the direct object” (1983: 281), as exemplified by the obligatory first person object agreement in (43b). Similarly, the Tzotzil verb agrees in animate number with promoted indirect objects but not demoted direct objects. She concludes, “There are three kinds of evidence that the initial indirect object is the final subject of the passive sentence: evidence from person agreement, number agreement, and word order” (1983: 282–283).

A lexicalist response to Aissen might be to view Tzotzil Goal phrases as simple variants of direct objects. We reproduce two of her arguments against this position: (i) The verbal suffix -be in (42–43), which we gloss as applicative, may not occur with simple transitives. (ii) A different verbal suffixation with -van, which indicates a discourse-specified human direct object, “is quite regular and . . . there appear to be no lexical exceptions” (1983: 292). However, this -van apparently marks only deep direct objects, since it cannot replace a subject of an intransitive complement to a causative (44b). The fact that (fully productive) -van is equally ungrammatical with an indirect object signaled by -be (44c) confirms that the latter cannot be a deep structure direct object either:

(44)
a. (causative with overt first person lower subject)
L-i-y-ak’ lok’-ik-on.
ASP-ABS1-ERG3-let leave-INTR-ABS1
‘He let me leave.’
b. (causative with discourse-specified human object)
*
I-
ak’-van lok’-uk.
ASP-let-OBJ leave-INTR
‘He let people leave.’
c. *Tas-čon-be-van čitom.
ASP-sell-APPL-OBJ pig
‘He is selling people pigs.’
That is, while the bare indirect objects of Tzotzil are indeed surface direct objects, they are not deep direct objects but rather advance to that position in a derivation.

subsection.heading:
3.2.4 Chiche
a
subsection.p:
On the basis of his work with Sam Mchombo, Baker (1988b) describes a range of double object properties of the Bantu language Chiche
a according to which bare indirect objects behave like direct objects, while the deep direct objects which follow them do not. Only the bare indirect object in Chiche
a (i) must be adjacent to the verb (1988b: 370); (ii) undergoes passivization in all dialects (1988b: 386); (iii) “can be expressed by the object prefix on the verb” (1998b: 354); and (iv) cannot be relativized in accord with the restriction (29):

(31)
a. Atsikana a-na-perek-er-a mfumu chitseko.
girl SP-PAST-hand-APPL-ASP chief door
b. *Iyi ndi mfumu imene ndi-na-nen-a kuti atsikana a-na-perek-er-a chitseko
This is chief which 1sS-PAST-say-ASP that girl SP-PAST-hand-APPL-ASP door

An additional property confirming the derived nature of the Chiche
a bare indirect object is the fact that it may not undergo Baker's ‘noun incorporation’; this possibility is reserved for nouns governed by the verb in deep structure (reminiscent of the Tzotzil suffix -van). Baker's structural explanation for these facts, while transformational, does not sanction any phrasal movement of NP within the VP, but rather employs ‘P-incorporation’ into the V; this incorporated P is the source of the Chiche
a applicative suffix. We return to his analysis in section 4.1.

subsection.heading: 3.2.5 Scandinavian
subsection.p: Mainland Scandinavian languages, lacking overt oblique case, have a fairly productive dative alternation similar to English, described in Holmberg and Platzack (1995). The bare indirect objects act like their English counterparts: they must precede and asymmetrically c-command the deep direct object and they freely passivize in either periphrastic or synthetic passives, as seen in (45b–d). As in all Germanic languages, there is no overt applicative morphology on the verb. The following examples are Swedish:

(45)
a. Johan visade mej en intressant bild
Johan showed me an interesting picture
b. (periphrastic passive)
Jag blev visad en intressant bild
I was shown an interesting picture
c. (synthetic passive)
Jag visades en intressant bild
I showed-PASS an interesting picture
d. Johan {blev förärad/ förärades} en medalj
Johan {was presented/ presented-PASS} a medal
The passive formed by moving the deep DO is apparently marginal in Swedish, but allowed with some verbs:

(46)
a. (periphrastic passive)
?Bilden blev visad mej tre gånger
the-picture was shown me three times
b. (synthetic passive)
?Bilden visades mej tre gånger
the-picture showed-PASS me three times
c. Medaljen {förärades/ blev förärad} Johan
the-medal {presented-PASS/ was presented} Johan

An informant reports that in Norwegian, IO and DO passives are apparently equally good, while Danish is said not to accept passivising the deep direct object in a double object construction. The analysis of Holmberg and Platzack (1995) is reviewed here in section 4.3.4.

subsection.heading: 3.2.6 English
subsection.p: This language is poor in diagnostics that syntactically distinguish a surface direct object among bare NPs. However, some can be constructed; cf. note 1.
