Emonds (1972a) tests the PP-like nature of the direct object in a double object construction by its interaction with intransitive prepositions (particles). Intransitive prepositions can follow a direct object, as shown in (47a), but not a PP, as shown in (47b):

(47)
a. The secretary sent a memo out to the committee.
Bill fixed a drink up for John at the party.
b. *The secretary sent a memo to the committee out.
*Bill fixed a drink for John up at the party.

For speakers who allow a particle at all within a double object construction (e.g., the authors), the first or promoted NP behaves like a direct object in (48a) while the second NP behaves like a PP, as seen by the ungrammaticality of the particles in (48b):

(48)
a. The secretary sent the committee out a memo.
Bill fixed John up a drink at the party.
b. *The secretary sent the committee a memo out.
*Bill fixed John a drink up at the party.

The pattern is considered to have quite different implications in analyses that group double objects into small clauses, such as Kayne (1984c) and Den Dikken (1995c: ch. 3). We return to their reinterpretations of (47b) and (48b) in section 4.2. 31

A second test distinguishing English derived direct objects from chômeur NPs involves shifted quantifiers. Chung (1976: 81–82) observes that in Indonesian, non-adjacent ‘floated’ quantifiers are fully acceptable as modifiers of subjects and direct objects, but not as modifiers of PPs or chômeurs. The same (admittedly rather weak) contrast holds in English, where the test concerns not quantifiers at the end of the clause as in Indonesian, but rather quantifiers shifted just to the right of the NP they modify. These NPs with floating modifiers can be either direct objects (49a) or promoted indirect objects (49b), but they cannot be PPs, as seen in (49c–d):

(49)
a. We sent the books all {by mail/to that man}.
I fixed those drinks both {with ice/for Sue}.
b. Mary {brought/sent} the boys {each/both} a present.
c. We sent a refund to those men (??all) by mail.
d. I fixed those drinks for the girls (??both) with ice.

In certain analyses of section 4, a demoted or chômeur NP is embedded inside an additional surface XP. Hence, like an object of a P, such an NP fails to properly c-command shifted quantifiers, which seems to be the correct empirical result:

(50)
We sent that man [XP [NP the books]] (??all) by mail.
I fixed Sue [XP [NP those drinks]] (??both) with ice.32

Summarizing, since an English quantifier can only shift to the right of an NP in direct object position, only the promoted NPs and not the chômeurs resulting from indirect object movement properly c-command these Q.

The diagnostics for surface objecthood from diverse languages, as reviewed throughout this section, seem to lead to an inescapable conclusion, reflecting Marantz's Generalization, that double object constructions (that is, those where neither object exhibits an overt oblique case) involve repositioning a deep indirect object in a derived direct object position:

(51)
Consensus on promotion:
Where a language systematically allows two surface NP objects indistinct from accusatives to have different theta-roles, the thematic or deep indirect object is structurally the surface direct object.

subsection.heading: 3.3 The Barss and Lasnik Binding paradigms
subsection.p: As observed in section 2.3, Barss and Lasnik (1986) discuss six different paradigms, widely thought to be best accounted for in terms of Chomsky's (1981: ch. 3) Binding Theory and c-command at LF. These paradigms require that the English promoted indirect object in a double object construction asymmetrically c-command the demoted or chômeur NP. The constructions include antecedent/bound anaphor pairings (e.g., send the two managers each other's foreman vs. *send each other's manager the two foremen), quantifier/bound singular pronoun pairing (e.g., every man, his), weak crossover paradigms, superiority restrictions on wh-extraction, and negative polarity pairings. It suffices to summarize here by observing that they are widely taken to establish the conclusion (52):

(52)
Consensus on superiority:
A promoted indirect object surfaces as asymmetrically ‘higher’ than a deep direct object.

Thus, there has also emerged a consensus concerning whether double object constructions are transformationally derived. Many authors now agree that they are, and the indirect or applied object surfaces in a direct object position asymmetrically higher than the deep direct object, which is somehow ‘demoted’. However, there is currently almost total disagreement as to how to best represent that demotion.

subsection.heading: 3.4 The position of the applicative affix
subsection.p: Provided we retain the right-hand headedness of English (and most other) morphology, there are only two possible structures (cf. section 2.5) for a null applicative affix on English double object verbs: a null grammatical head V, as proposed in Marantz (1993), or an incorporated P:

We have seen throughout sections 1 and 3 that overt applicative affixes are generally suffixes across languages. Unsurprisingly then, Baker's (1988a–b), which derives them by head movement of P into V (cf. section 4.1), represents the incorporated applicative P as a suffix. However, in a clear majority of well-motivated head movements that give rise to single words, such as noun incorporation and V-raising, a moved head becomes a prefix. This discrepancy in morpheme order within a V then suggests the correctness of (25a) for representing applicatives.

Indeed, the morphemes for the benefactive applicatives in head-final Korean VPs (Choe 1986) and the dative applicatives in complement-final Chinese VPs (Huang 1991) can both alternatively appear as independent V glossed as ‘give’ in those languages. Moreover, the Korean applicative verb cwu- takes the full range of the morphology associated with that language's verbs. Thus, we do not hesitate to hypothesize that applicative suffixes, both overt and covert, are uniformly of category V, in accord with the expectations of Lieber's (1980) and Williams's (1981b) word-internal Right Hand Head Rules.

Assigning applicative suffixes to the category V additionally explains why languages fail to have parallel constructions in other types of phrasal projections; the complex V structure of (25a) but not the P-incorporation of (25b) accounts for the cross-linguistic impossibility of applicative nouns or applicative adjectives, for example. 33

subsection.heading: 4 The ongoing debate: the position of the direct object in the presence of promotion
4.1 Double objects result from incorporation of a null Case-marker
subsection.p: Most Relational Grammar analyses have consistently argued that an indirect object (‘an initial 3’) in applicative constructions simply replaces the direct object (‘becomes a final 2’). From this it correctly follows that promoted indirect objects act as direct objects with respect to later processes that depend on the final grammatical status of an NP, exactly as required by the considerations of section 3.2. Under this view, the (optional) fate of a deep or initial direct object in RG is to be demoted into the ‘chômeur’ (unemployed) status of Perlmutter and Postal (1983b), though still remaining vaguely associated with the main verb. In phrase structural terms, the demoted deep object NP remains somewhere in the deep VP.

However, both promotion and demotion within VP contravene Chomsky's (1981) Projection Principle, at least as it has been widely understood. Thus, the Relational Grammar conception of ‘3 to 2 advancement’, translated into Government-Binding terms, violates the usual formulation of the Projection Principle twice.

One way to ensure that a promoted indirect object both acts as a direct object for several syntactic processes and at the same time asymmetrically c-commands an RG chômeur is to claim that the required surface relation of the double objects is simply their deep relation. That is, no NP movement or promotion occurs. This can be implemented by postulating that some empty (surface) P introduces the thematic direct object, as in (53):

This is Pesetsky's (1995: 125) proposal: “The second object of a double object construction . . . is [an NP] introduced by a null Case-assigning element G.” This empty G selects an NP with a ‘Theme’ semantic role (i.e., a direct object) and “must move from its base position [in (53)] and affix . . . to the governing verb” (1995: 127). Pesetsky goes on to discuss various possibilities for fixing the category of G, and tentatively concludes that the best candidate is P. 34

Pesetsky's hypothesis provides a simple theory of structure-dependent case-assignment (one case-assigner for each NP; section 1.2) as well as an explanation for the non-productivity of the English double object construction (section 2.5). Nonetheless, it reduces to a latter-day version of lexicalism, since the incorporation of P plays no structural role in either the syntax or the interpretation of the two NPs. Its disadvantages are consequently due to the fact that the bare indirect object has no transformationally derived character: (i) Anderson's (1971) general semantic properties of direct objects, which promoted indirect objects lack, become stipulated aspects of the item G (Pesetsky 1995: 179–180); (ii) the base structure (53) cannot explain the Restriction on A′-extraction (29); (iii) Aissen's (1983) arguments against deep representations like (53) for Tzotzil go unanswered (section 3.2.3); (iv) there is no explanation for why promoted indirect object nouns exhibit ‘Scope Freezing’ (section 3.1.3) or cannot undergo the further step of incorporation in a language with that option (Baker 1988b).

In addition, overt applicative realizations of incorporated Ps are generally homophonous with Goal rather than Theme prepositions (e.g., Chinese gei ‘to’; Zhang 1990); this tendency creates awkwardness for the structure (53).

Pesetsky's proposal is structurally similar to, but derivationally distinct from, an earlier, extremely influential proposal of Baker's (1988a, 1988b). Baker accounts for Marantz's Generalization by a variant of (53) in which a null surface P introduces the first (indirect) rather than the second (direct) object. Unlike Kayne's earlier proposal for an empty P which remains in situ, discussed above in section 2.4, Baker claims that a deep P transformationally incorporates into V, leaving a trace and surfacing as overt dative and benefactive applicative morphemes, as in the Chiche
a illustration (54):

According to Baker, an empty P cannot govern or assign case to its object, so this NP must receive case from some other source. He achieves this and explains many other derived direct object properties of RG's promoted indirect objects by utilizing his quite convincing and general Government Transparency Corollary (Baker 1988a: 64). According to this proposal, if a head Y (here P) adjoins to a higher head Z (here V), then a phrase otherwise governed by Y becomes governed by Z. Since the complex V (V + P) in (54) then governs the stranded NP, the latter is assigned accusative and treated as a direct object. Incorporation and Government Transparency thus together account for the fact that deep oblique NPs can behave as surface direct objects. To further ground this system empirically, Baker (1988a: ch. 5) surveys in detail several properties of applicative systems rather schematically reviewed in section 3.2 above. 35

Baker's and Pesetsky's analyses of double object constructions have in common that they respect the standard interpretation of Chomsky's (1981) Projection Principle: neither analysis modifies the position of any complement NP in the course of a derivation, and consequently no single VP contains multiple links in a single argument chain. A further merit of Baker's framework is that transformational P-incorporation (a subcase of head movement) accounts for the difference between the deep and surface status of the bare indirect object; this ‘inner NP’ is governed by P in deep structure and hence lacks properties of deep direct objects, but by V in surface structure, whereby it acquires direct object properties through Government Transparency.

Baker's ‘transformationalist incorporation’ (54) is supported by several intricate properties of the applicative systems he examines, and it escapes the criticisms we levelled against Pesetsky's ‘lexicalist incorporation’ analysis (53). Nonetheless, (54) appears to have two serious weaknesses. First, the asymmetric c-command required for the paradigms of Barss and Lasnik (1986) is exactly the opposite of that in (54), as observed in Emonds (1993), Marantz (1993), and Pesetsky (1995). Since the deep direct object asymmetrically c-commands the indirect object at the end of the derivation, the binding properties holding between double objects should be the opposite of what holds for English double objects, or at least the second ‘outer’ NP should act like it c-commands the first.

Second, Baker is left without a general device by which the deep or ‘demoted’ direct objects in (54) can acquire case, or at least pass the Case Filter. Consequently, he develops two alternatives in his section 5.3.4, one in terms of a highly stipulative extension of case theory and a second in terms of a rather abstract ‘LF incorporation’ of the thematic direct object (thus exempting it from the Case Filter in his system). The revised case theory not only subscribes to a non-explanatory notion of autonomous case (cf. section 1.2), but also extends the inherent vs. structural case dichotomy in several directions. 36 Pesetsky's (1995) variant on Baker's incorporation is in fact principally motivated by his explicitly less baroque view of case assignment.

Baker's second alternative for satisfying the Case Filter abandons assigning case to the second NP in a double object construction. Rather, he proposes ‘N-incorporation in LF’ for the chômeur of the dative alternation which would otherwise violate case theory. This sidestepping of the Case Filter seems to be pretty much an untestable hypothesis, though he tries to turn the obligatory incorporation of second objects in Southern Tiwa applicatives to his advantage. 37 It is hard not to conclude that such purely abstract use of incorporation has no effect other than rendering the incorporated constituents essentially exempt from any claims of grammatical theory.

Finally, although Baker's structure (54) provides a means for formulating a ‘Non-Oblique Trace Filter’ to explain the Restriction on A′-extraction (29), the actual formulation and workings of his filter seem ad hoc (cf. section 3.1.2).

subsection.heading: 4.2 Double objects are two arguments in small clauses
subsection.p: Several Government and Binding authors have proposed that double object structures in Germanic languages are in fact grouped into single constituents. The indirect object and the direct object are then respectively taken to be the surface subject (or ‘Specifier’) and the object (or ‘Complement’) inside this constituent. Disputes concern the exact categorical nature of this putative phrase and its head, which we can here call neutrally ‘XP’, as well as the issue of whether the surface position of the IO in (55) is base-generated or derived by movement:

Provided that the ‘subject’ IO is higher than the ‘complement’ DO in the surface form of XP, all these analyses can account for the consensus on superiority (52), i.e., the paradigms in Barss and Lasnik (1986), whether or not they predate that article. If an analysis utilizes the XP structure so as to move the indirect object to its surface position in (55), presumably into SPEC(XP), the analysis also has a good chance of capturing the ways the IO doesn't act like a deep direct object (51), as well as the further Restriction on A′-movement (29).

However, in all these analyses, the internal structures attributed to each author's categorial choice for the XP remain fairly problematic. It should be kept in mind that overt ‘internal NP subjects’ of categories other than IP and DP are actually never attested in English in diagnostic positions such as a focus in clefts or pseudo-clefts. These ‘object phrase’ analyses moreover typically require that V govern across the XP boundary into the SPEC position, not only for assigning case to the IO but also for the several other surface object properties brought out especially in Relational Grammar studies (cf. section 3.2). Few of these analyses make any attempt to either broadly justify or precisely define this kind of governance, exceptions being Kayne (1981c) and Den Dikken (1995c).

Especially when XP in a structure like (55) is not some projection of V, it is customary to refer to it as a ‘small clause’ (i.e., a clause-like structure lacking many – or nearly all – clausal properties). The choices for XP can be IP (formerly S) or PP, reviewed in this section, or NP/DP, reviewed in section 4.4. The choice of VP for XP (‘Larsonian shells’) is reviewed in section 4.3.

subsection.heading: 4.2.1 Some doubts about small clauses
subsection.p: Kayne (1981c) proposes that trees must be binary branching, which leads him to conclude that double objects form a constituent rather than each being a sister to V. As the binary branching hypothesis has been so influential, practically blinding the field in our opinion to any approach inconsistent with it, it is worth looking into the justifications given for it.

Kayne's (1981c) initial justification for binary branching is a purely formal exercise. A type of tree relation between antecedents and traces alluringly named an ‘unambiguous path’ is shown to be compatible only with binary branching trees. 38 However, as the article's first section indicates, there is nothing ‘unambiguous’ in binary trees about the actual location of an antecedent; in order to find an anaphor's antecedent, the direction ‘up or down’ in the tree must be specified independently at each dominating node. That is, specifying unambiguous paths to an antecedent is simply a formal equivalent to specifying c-command over strings of variable length.

Subsequently, Kayne (1984c) presents theoretical and empirical arguments to motivate binary branching and hence small clause structures for English double objects. We first treat in turn four considerations that seem to have impressed subsequent analysts: (i) an argument based on learnability, (ii) the relation of binary branching to Kayne's theory of ‘connectedness’, (iii) the way Kayne insulates small clause theory from disconfirmation, and (iv) argumentation based on coordinations. We delay until the next subsection his proposal for English paradigms with particles, (47–48) above, which bear more directly on double objects. 39

(i) Learnability. Kayne (1984c: ix) remarks that binary branching “constitutes a step towards a solution to the learnability problem for phrase structure (How does the language learner know what tree representation, of all those available in theory, to associate with a given sentence?).” This remark has impressed later researchers, being echoed for example in Den Dikken (1995c: 27). But in fact binary branching does not reduce the set of grammars, since learned parts of grammars, probably the lexical entries of functional categories, actually contain no information about branching. Rather, as Kayne's cited rhetorical question indicates, binary branching can facilitate not acquisition but processing. It can (only) help associate given sentences with certain trees rather than others.

But to our knowledge, procedures that have been implemented for processing models invariably use the argument-taking devices of heads in a central way, whether these be thought of as argument structures, theta-grids, lexical conceptual structures, event structures, or subcategorization frames. In these procedures, an indispensable step in either producing or comprehending a sentence of any complexity is always (56):

(56)
Economy of representation:
Match the lexical argument information of a head with a syntactic tree, using as little structure as possible.
If no structural economy were built into using argument information, arguments could be located anywhere – not even near the head in question.

Now binary branching suggests no way to eliminate or supplant (56). But given (56), there is no processing reason for associating arguments with a head by any means other than sisterhood; sisterhood is required whenever it is possible. Of course, research has revealed many grammatical reasons for positing a non-sister relation between heads and their subjects, so-called ‘external arguments’, independently of any concerns here with double objects. However, has it found comparable reasons for any non-sister relation for ‘internal arguments’, which should be similarly justified? Our evaluations below of many proposals for such non-sister complement structures suggest rather that binary branching results in convoluted and inadequate analyses.

Consequently, not only is binary branching unrelated to language acquisition, in models of sentence processing it at best supplements economy of representation (56). We thus cannot agree with Den Dikken (1995c: 28), who claims that small clauses “are available at no cost whatsoever.” We rather feel that their additional structure must be empirically justified by improved characterizations of paradigms involving double complements. 40

(ii) Connectedness. In an impressive series of detailed analyses of extraction and movement phenomena, Kayne (1981a, 1981c, 1983) develops a theory of “connectedness” in trees which is designed to account for a number of paradigms involving extractions, parasitic gaps, multiple questions, etc. These papers do not discuss binary branching (or double objects), but it is true enough that researchers such as Den Dikken (1995c: 28) often conceptualize or explicate this theory in terms of binary branching trees.

Nonetheless, the connectedness results can be recast without binary branching, although to demonstrate this in detail would require a paper in itself. Informally, Kayne's final statement of connectedness (1983) requires the deepest variables bound by operators to be terminal right branches; nothing mentions a left branch, i.e., a subject of a small clause. An alternative formulation that Kayne (1981c: note 36) himself cites is the analysis of Koster (1978b: ch. 2); we are more familiar with a slightly different version in Koster (1978a), called there the Nesting Hypothesis. 41 We would reformulate the latter in terms of prohibiting material to the right of the most embedded bound category it applies to; such an approach to the material treated under the rubric of connectedness does not refer to branching at all. Thus, binary branching is not an intrinsic ingredient of connectedness or more generally of successful theories of movement and extraction.

(iii) Insulation. Binary branching depends very much on small clause (‘SC’) analyses for many double complement structures. Yet the following assumptions largely ‘insulate’ small clause theory from disconfirmation: “Taking small clauses to be maximal projections . . . , [they are] transparent to government only when the governor and the maximal projection are sisters” (Kayne 1984c: x) and “N cannot govern across a boundary” (1981c: section 3.2). Thus, if a small clause in its base position is a sister to V, it acts as though it isn't there (due to transparency). If it is anywhere else (moved or a sister to N or base-generated in some ungoverned position), it also acts as if it isn't there, because its subjects (at least those Kayne discusses) are in need of case, which they cannot get in any of these positions. Consequently, the general way to test for presence of a constituent in generative grammar, namely movement (Ross 1986), is rendered inoperative. Even strong supporters of small clause structures agree with this observation (Den Dikken 1995c: 47, 61). So finally, a small clause ends up acting syntactically as if it isn't there; it plays no role in movement or in limiting movement. 42

On this point, a referee correctly observes that normal clauses (IPs) also often act “as if they aren't there”; they don't move away from their introductory C and, when non-finite, are not barriers to case-marking from the outside. But these observations simply underscore the tenuous status of IP itself (as a binary branching daughter of a projection of C). This weakness doesn't argue for small clauses, but rather undercuts even Bresnan's (1970) binary division between C and IP. Nonetheless, she supported her division by noting that parentheticals can divide C and IP. The Board will declare {that/whether}, during the past year, the company has been profitable. Such parentheticals are unacceptable with small clauses: ?? The Board will declare, during the past year, the company profitable. This difference implies that there are no positive diagnostics for small clause constituency.

Of course, the question remains: is insulation from disconfirmation, achieved for SCs by Kayne's two cited theoretical stipulations, a good thing or a bad one? Several researchers seem to feel that it provides a kind of license for ubiquitous small clause structures. But insulation from disconfirmation cannot in itself constitute a reason to reject alternatives using ternary branching for representing double objects, which after all accords with a straightforward interpretation of economy of representation (56).

(iv) Coordination. Small clauses might be motivated by paradigms based on coordinations (or deletions) rather than movement. For example, authors sometimes cite coordinations as in (57) as support for small clause constituents:
(57) John [VP turned [SC [SC the heat up] and [SC the air conditioning down]]].
But these sequences are arguably reductions of coordinate VP or IP with an empty second V as in (58), parallel to similar coordinate sequences as in (59):
(58) John [VP [VP [V turned] [NP the heat] up] and [VP [V Ø] [NP the air conditioning] down]].

(59)
He [VP [VP [V misses] [NP his wife] on Saturday] and [VP [V Ø] [NP his friends] on Sunday]].
John [VP [VP [V thought] of [NP Mary] mornings] and [VP [V Ø] of [NP Sara] at midnight]].
These latter can't be small clauses since the combinations his wife on Saturday, Mary mornings, etc. are not predications.

The possibility of replacing and in both (58) and (59) with but, as in (60a), is also telling. This is a possible clausal coordination pattern for root predications, as in the structures in (58–59). However, a coordination of clausal complements as in (60b), whether they be SCs or of any other type, would require a not after but:

(60)
a. John turned the heat up but the air conditioning down.
He avoids his wife on Saturday but his friends on Sunday.
John thought of Mary mornings but of Sara at midnight.
Mary should come inside but keep a coat on.
b. They should avoid coming inside {and/*but} keeping a coat on.
Permission to come inside {and/*but} to keep a coat on is rarely given.
Thus, more complete coordination paradigms reveal the inadequacy of SC analyses such as (57) and support rather an alternative in terms of coordinated VPs with an empty second V, as in (58). 43

subsection.heading: 4.2.2 Sentence-based small clauses
subsection.p: Whatever one's theoretical predispositions with respect to small clauses, analyses using them must still be evaluated on their empirical merits. So let us now turn to the argumentation in Kayne (1981c, 1984c) for grouping English indirect and direct objects together as small clauses.

In Kayne's (1981c: sections 2.2–2.3) first proposal, the small clause XP over English IOs and DOs is an S. It neither is endocentric nor places the IO higher than the DO. In a second proposal (Kayne 1984b) (inferred from his note 5, “it now seems preferable to follow Stowell,” and from his page xi), XP is apparently NP; the bold sequence in send [NP [PP Mary] [NP Bill's book]] presumably has the curious form [NP[PP[P Ø] NP] − NP].

Kayne (1981c) makes a detailed argument for these SCs based on their being impossible in English nominalizations, crucially using his postulate that “N cannot govern across a boundary.” Consequently, a prepositionless indirect object cannot properly receive case inside a nominalization because the small clause boundary insulates it from government. This argument could extend to other small clause analyses of double objects, as their proponents are doubtless aware. But in competing transformational accounts, any promotion of indirect objects in an NP domain will necessarily place them in a PP so that they can receive case. But then they will not c-command their base position, i.e., their traces will be improperly bound. Such considerations equally well explain the absence of double object constructions in NPs. So Kayne's influential nominalization argument in favor of double object small clauses is not definitive. 44

As another argument for analyzing double objects as small clauses, Kayne (1983c) uses the ordering restriction illustrated in (61), according to which English intransitive [PP P] must precede [PP P − XP] (Emonds 1972a):

(61)
a. The secretary sent a memo out to the committee.
They are trying to make John out a liar.
b. *The secretary sent a memo to the committee out.
*They are trying to make John a liar out.

Kayne excludes (61b) by means of ‘recursive small clauses’ as in make [YP [XP [NP John] [X’ a liar]] [Y out]]. Since make is not a sister of XP, the latter's subject is ungoverned, hence not assigned case, hence ungrammatical. However, his discussion provides no indication of how this small clause structure contributes to meaning. Thus, the sharply different SCs for the synonymous pair (62) would apparently have no effect on meaning:

(62)
a. send [SC a memo out] to the committee
b. send [SC [SC the committee out] a memo]

Additionally, the fact that (62b) is good for many speakers, including the authors, disconfirms Kayne's account of (61b), since his proposal rules out (62b) on exactly the same grounds as (61b). Moreover, the very fact that these small clause structures seem scattered about with no specification of their distribution is highly suspect.

Finally, consider the secondary predication bring John his food cold. While recursive small clause structures (AP inside YP) might accommodate bring [YP [John] [Y Ø] [AP [his food] [A cold]]], an identical bracketing could also tolerate *make John a liar out. A solution might consist of imposing an ordering restriction on intransitive P as heads of SCs, thereby bringing us back to the starting point of Emonds (1972a). Consequently, the restriction evidenced in (61b) ends up providing no evidence of small clause structure.

There thus seem to be no real arguments for double object small clauses in Kayne (1984c), nor do the theoretical acquisition or connectedness considerations often advanced in their favor have any force. The structures themselves have significant drawbacks, as mentioned in the discussions of the SCs in (61) and (62). To these can be added the oddity of their internal structure, as seen in (62). The only consideration that remains in their favor is Kayne's (1981c) account of why they do not occur in English nominalizations, an account that we feel could be challenged along the lines indicated above.

subsection.heading: 4.2.3 PP-based small clauses
subsection.p: Den Dikken (1995c: ch. 3) provides a more carefully designed and defended SC analysis of English double objects as complex PPs, with special attention to their properties when they occur with particles (‘Prt’), as in John sent Bob off a package. 45 By applying Baker's (1988a) Uniformity of Theta Assignment Hypothesis (‘UTAH’), he defends his cross-linguistic proposals with argumentation based on Dutch and Chinese double object constructions as well. While the author explicitly bases his SC framework on the dubious theoretical motivations for small clauses (learnability, connectedness, and binary branching), his extensive argumentation does not entirely rest on them, and hence must be independently evaluated.

Aspects of Den Dikken's analysis derive from his assumptions that SCs (i) “are available at no cost whatsoever,” (ii) “are the sole incarnation of subject predicate relationships,” and hence (iii) “all share the semantic aspect of property ascription” 46 (1995c: 24–25, 28). His resulting SC structures, which he considers costless, are in our view somewhat arbitrary, as per our section 4.2.1. That is, they don't satisfy movement diagnostics for PPs, and moreover the mechanisms for how predicates select them are not specified.

The center of his analysis is that English postverbal particles are ‘unaccusative’ P heads of SCs. Deep structure PPs for double objects with particles therefore contain two small clauses, as in (63): 47

Den Dikken (1995c: sections 3.7–3.8) further claims that a third empty headed verbal small clause SC′ above (63) provides additional surface housing for a sequence NP + Prt, for theoretical reasons related to PPs but extraneous to the double object NPs.

By the time Den Dikken provides some motivation for all three of these small clauses and for the various mechanisms that finally ensure word orders and case-marking, his analysis becomes baroque; the biggest questions then concern whether all the various steps in his undeniably careful analysis really have independent justification or plausibility on the basis of other constructions. Two examples: (i) The direct object in To Mary was given a book receives nominative case through a sort of extended chain that involves a case-marked PP in subject position, its trace, and SPEC–HEAD agreement with this trace inside one of the small clauses (1995c: 119). (ii) Postverbal particles in structures such as send off Bill a package obligatorily incorporate into otherwise empty small clause verbal heads that follow the main verb.

Nonetheless, parts of Den Dikken's analysis seem convincing. For instance, he constructs some arguments based on Dutch and Chinese for an empty P even in deep structures for double objects without particles (1995c: sections 3.11–3.13). By cross-linguistic similarity (i.e., using Baker's Uniformity of Theta Asssignment Hypothesis), he concludes that a lexical Prt can also be null and thus that (64) (cf. his tree (63)) must be part of the general deep structure for English double object constructions: 48

Let us examine his proposal that the top SC should be embedded in a third SC′ (actually a bare VP) which mediates between the lexical V and the Prt heads. A central motivation for this empty V head above SC in (63–64) is its role as a target for incorporating the lowest (case-assigning) Goal P, which then assigns case to the Theme NP in send Bob off a package, as illustrated in Den Dikken's (1995c: 133) final labeled bracketing for (63). 49 While the author's argument may be a legitimate use of Baker's (1988a) Government Transparency Corollary, if we stand back a bit the consequences seem bizarre. The implication is that a P heading a complement (the lower SC) within a clause (the upper SC) can, with enough gymnastics, move into the very head that selects that clause, analogous to operations on a sequence make Bill blame the accident on Harry by which the P on would finally incorporate into make, skipping over blame, and then assign case to Bill.

To us, these machinations bring up the following overriding issue: if Principles and Parameters systems permit such an analysis, with its extra abstract V predicate and attendant complex case-marking and chains of co-indexing, it seems likely that the systems themselves are underconstrained. Alternatively, one could set out to show that such incorporations (i.e., sidestepping of ‘head to head’ movement) are really needed in a range of other, possibly similar constructions – or that such incorporations are excluded in principle save in just the case under discussion. But only such wider justifications can dispel doubts about proposals as internally complex as Den Dikken's intricate case-marking for the Theme NP in a double object construction. We therefore are critical of the additional SC′ above the double object deep structure PP in (64).

One might try to eliminate this higher abstract V and retain only two SCs in Den Dikken's (63–64) by reworking his case assignment, perhaps by making particles ‘optionally’ unaccusative. Two reasons for not doing this is that the bolded up the number and the number up will then both be PPs in such classic examples as (65), and they must both be insulated against PP movement, which seems difficult. Small clauses are generally insulated from movement because their subject NP would lack a case-assigner, as discussed earlier; but the sequence up the number should be able to move if it were analyzed as a PP:

(65)
John looked up the number.
John looked the number up.

A final doubt about an SC account of double objects concerns economy of representation as expressed in (56). If indeed a single PP small clause can encompass both a DO in its specifier, case-marked by a higher head, and an IO complement to its head (e.g., to), why should these two NP arguments of a V ever be realized inside some more complex structure which licenses bare IOs? This question seems to loom over Den Dikken's – and other – small clause analyses of double objects; any such structure that is more complex than a transitive verb with an indirect object marked by a P should be ruled out by Economy.

subsection.heading: 4.3 Double objects are two arguments in lower verb phrases
4.3.1 Larsonian shells
subsection.p: Working in a Government-Binding framework, Larson (1988b, 1990) makes a proposal for double object constructions now known as a ‘Larsonian shell’. He agrees with Relational Grammar in promoting indirect objects to direct object status and demoting the original direct object, thereby expressing the asymmetric c-command required by the paradigms of Barss and Lasnik (1986).

The particularity of Larson's analysis is its deep structure; the double object construction is a deep VP complement to a higher empty V as in (66). In this complement (i) only the indirect object PP has complement status, (ii) a direct object begins in a deep VP Specifier position, and (iii) the empty head of a postulated higher VP is a landing site for an eventual V-raising. Larson considers the direct object of the double object construction the ‘deep subject’ of a lower VP. The latter cannot receive case in this position unless the lexical V raises to a position outside the lower VP where it governs and hence can case-mark the NP in this Specifier position:

Larson derives the double object construction by what he claims to be a passive-like movement of the indirect object. A different execution of this basic idea is proposed in Aoun and Li (1989, 1993b), as reviewed in the next subsection.

In Government and Binding terms, the dative operation absorbs or withdraws case from the ‘object’ of the verb in (66) (that is, the indirect object) and suppresses the theta-role of the ‘subject’ (the direct object). 50 The deep direct object simultaneously becomes an adjunct of the V′, partly parallel to the by phrase of passives. The indirect object can then move to the ‘VP subject’ position, analogous to a passivized subject:

When the indirect object moves up to the inner subject position, it asymmetrically c-commands the second NP, and receives case from the raised verb. The adjunct direct object is assigned case by the lowest V′, which is curiously reanalyzed as a V even though it contains a phrasal trace. Den Dikken (1995c: section 3.2) scrutinizes the possible effects of Larson's reanalysis, and concludes that it especially faces problems with respect to the English paradigms in which particles combine with double objects.

A number of other oddities result from analyzing a direct object as an adjunct: (i) unlike other adjuncts, the direct object is often obligatory; (ii) it receives case from the head of its phrasal sister (unlike adjunct agent phrases in the standard passive, which require a P); (iii) it freely undergoes successive cyclic A′-movement, counter to a usual restriction on adjuncts (e.g., What did Mary know how to send John?). In contrast, Larson's derived position for a promoted indirect object is exactly that of a true deep direct object. Consequently, the IO in a double object construction should undergo A′-movement, contrary to the descriptive generalization (29). Larson does discuss some of these problems (1988b: section 3.3), but to our mind unpersuasively.

The widespread adoption of Larson's complex analysis may be largely due to its compatibility with other influential contemporary ideas. As observed above, Kayne (1981c, 1984c) has convinced most syntacticians to limit trees to binary branching, yet his initial recasting of head-initial double object constructions in binary trees led to his rather problematic category labels for double object small clause structures (see section 4.2.2). Alternative binary structures like [[V − NP] − {NP/PP}], in which the surface direct object follows and asymmetrically c-commands the indirect object, would wreak havoc with the Barss and Lasnik (1986) paradigms.

Larson's structure (66) seems to remove these problems, thus clearing the way for binary structures via his structural ‘Single Complement Condition’. This basis for binary branching seems like an independent advantage, although its proponents have not seriously addressed a host of other double complement constructions for which the Barss and Lasnik arguments would demand similar treatment. Their properties continue to challenge proponents of binary branching, whatever the correct analysis of double objects. 51

Shell structures raise other questions not yet adequately addressed. 52 For example, why can't the lower VP complement of the empty V in (66) be replaced by an NP such as good ideas, deriving (via head movement of N substituting for the empty V) a word salad something like *John did(n't)[VP ideasi [NP good ti]? Perhaps Larson (1990: 597–598) intends to answer this by the claim that if a V's arguments “can't be fitted into the minimal VP that it heads, this forces an upward branching of X-bar structure to secure an argument position for the agent.” But then this stipulation, to the effect that a shell over an XP ‘can be’ of the same category XP, should be strengthened to ‘must be’. Indeed, rather late in the presentation, Larson (1988b: sections 7.1–7.2) claims that an argument of α must always be realized within some (possibly higher but presumably adjacent) projection of α.

Additionally, one wonders if these are the only shells possible. That is, are there also cases of empty-headed APs over APs, etc? Along the same lines, nothing prevents lexical entries from multiplying the number of shells for single items. The Larsonian framework, far from limiting the number of a verb's complements (as is often inferred from his Single Complement Hypothesis), makes no claim about the maximal number of arguments for a single predicate. 53

If send is truly an intransitive verb with an inanimate subject (Larson 1988b: 342), we should be seriously rethinking the nature of lexical entries, since apparently the frames of verbs are nothing like what they appear to be. But in fact, is there independent support for treating an indirect object as the sole deep complement of apparent di-transitive verbs? Larson's (1988b: 340–341) two arguments for such a V′ constituent, based on idioms and a suggested closer semantic link between verbs and their indirect objects, are impressionistic and unconvincing (Emonds 1993: 220–221). 54

Larson (1990: section 5.3) further argues for his constituent structure with a claim that both gapping and pseudo-gapping can delete a V′ constituent which unites verbs and indirect objects in (66). However, finding contrasts in pairs like (68) that would support this claim is difficult; the (a) examples, in which V′ deletes, don't seem to contrast with those in (b), in which V′ is supposedly not available:

(68)
a. ??He sends love letters to Mary and she [V′ Ø] dessert recipes.
Bill fixes martinis for us more often than he {did/would}[V′ Ø] manhattans.
b. ??He sends love letters to Mary and she to Bill.
Bill fixes martinis more often for us than he {did/would} for you.55

Finally, Larson's case theory is sui generis. He tacitly assumes that the demoted deep object cannot be within a PP, perhaps in deference to the widely shared view that the Projection Principle forbids lowering. Consequently, to explain how a single verb essentially assigns case twice, he assumes that a V assigns both an inherent and a structural objective case. A typical transitive verb is taken to assign both inherent and structural case to its direct object, in contrast to standard variants of case theory. Then, when a double object construction is present, the cases can be split: the indirect object receives structural objective case and the direct object inherent objective case. Within this rather elaborate framework, both cases are suppressed for passive formation, but only structural case for dative shift. Larson also claims that Infl (I) is required for the assignment of objective case, although participles and restructuring verbs (which can be transitive) can be argued to lack I (cf. note 53).

On the positive side, Larson's analysis accounts for the Barss-Lasnik paradigms in both the base and permuted versions of double object constructions. Moreover, in spite of the marginal role assigned to PP structures, Larson (1988b: section 5) provides a valuable discussion of the complementary roles of the contentful English Ps to, of, from vs. the applicative suffixes in other languages (the former typically blocking dative interchange and the latter licensing it). The virtues aside, we have not concealed the fact that we find much to question in this influential account. What seems strange is not the author's proposal, but the way in which, in spite of their many problematic aspects, Larsonian shells quickly became the standard basis for treating double objects.

subsection.heading: 4.3.2 Reversing Larson's order of arguments
subsection.p: As discussed in section 2.1, several authors claim that the double object construction indicates a kind of possession of the direct object by the indirect object, even though verbs such as offer, sing, and read make this doubtful. Partly to express this putative property, Aoun and Li (1989) propose that double object constructions are small clauses (SC) of indeterminate category, headed by an empty V of possession, as in (69):

How to determine the category label and distribution of this small clause structure is left vague; apparently all and only lexical entries for double object verbs stipulate this type of clausal complement with an SC subcategorization frame. However, the many verbs of transfer that do not allow double objects (section 2.5) will either have quite different complement structures, or the argument interchange in their SC complement (a counterpart to Larson's ‘passive’ account of dative movement) must be obligatory for such verbs.

Another problem with (69), which is base-generated for Aoun and Li, is that we would expect the indirect object to freely undergo A′-movement just as subjects of other supposed small clauses do (e.g., in consider John foolish, etc.). But as observed in the discussion of the Restriction on A′-extraction in section 3.1, this is not the case.

Further questions must be asked in order to evaluate the structure in (69). Why should an empty V be restricted to small clauses, when verbs generally occur in all types of clausal structures? 56 As with Larson's account, what restricts the number of shells contained within each other? Why does the passive form of [V e] mark its postposed subject with to or for, while other passive verbs induce by, and why is there no passive auxiliary in only this new type of passive?

In spite of these problems, the main proposal that Aoun and Li (1989) are arguing for is a theory of quantifiers that depends only on the configuration of dominance relations. Our many questions about the labels and provenance of their structures may therefore not seriously undermine their principal hypotheses, which concern the interpretation of quantifiers.

subsection.heading: 4.3.3 Lexical alternation in Larsonian shells
subsection.p: Bowers (1993: section 4) presents a critique of Larson's proposal to assimilate the dative alternation to that of passives, as well as a revised analysis that circumvents some of the attendant problems. This revised proposal uses a variant of shell structures to account for both the double object and the prepositional dative constructions, but considers the relation between them to be akin to a lexical causative alternation; that is, give with double objects realizes the structure of make IO own/have DO, with give raising from a lower to a higher V position. In comparison, the prepositional construction with give realizes make IO belong to DO, with the double object verb again raising to the V head of the higher VP shell.

Bowers's main innovation is to revise – in fact, expand – shell structures in terms of his study's general theory of predication, which posits (for small clause constructions as well) an alternating sequence of Pr(edicate)P and VP shells. This alternation is achieved by some phrase structure conditions (1993: 595), which force a sequence of dominance relations (70) in which each phrase's Specifier position houses an NP argument of the deep lexical verb. The lexical V starts from the lower V position and raises to the higher one, so as to provide case for the ‘inner NP’ whose surface position is the Spec of the higher VP. According to Bowers, NPs in the double object construction are positioned in the surface as follows, with their roles as subscripts:
(70) [PrP NPSUBJ Pr [VP NPIO V [PrP tIO Pr [VP NPDO V]]]]
The four bold nodes in (70) indicate overt morphemes for a simple sentence such as We sent Mary books.

Bowers is naturally concerned to show that his analysis improves on that of Larson. Thus, he criticizes aspects of Larson's case-assignment mechanisms and the proposal that the DO in a double object construction is in a transformationally adjoined position; our criticisms of Larson concerning (67) above in this respect recapitulate his. For Bowers (1993: 598), Larson doesn't propose enough structure; rather, all three arguments in a double object construction have properties of underlying subjects (uniformly identified with SPEC positions), as expressed in (70). This structure permits all three to c-command (non-final) floating quantifiers (including crucially We sent the boys all a book; ? we sent John the books all in nice packages; we sent the books all to John); but see note 32. It also permits the ‘outer object’ to be modified by secondary predication (We sent John the food cold), which is not ordinarily allowed for adjunct NPs.

While it does not come across as the author's main point, a lexicalist approach to double objects under any guise seems to us to fly in the face of the accumulated cross-linguistic arguments reviewed in section 3 in favor of accounting for the dative alternation transformationally. Moreover, while give may well paraphrase both make own and make belong to, we cannot carry the analogy much further: what pairs of causatives are paraphrased by double object verbs like promise, sing, write, butter, carve, cook, and fix? That is, in spite of its rather elaborate transformational raising and phrase structure, including a novel head category Pr uninstantiated in the lexicon, Bowers's analysis is lexicalist, by his own account (1993: 643–644). 57 Perhaps it is not inherently so, but as it stands it is.

subsection.heading: 4.3.4 Presence or absence of morphological case
subsection.p: For double objects in Mainland Scandinavian, Holmberg and Platzack (1995: 191) posit a deep structure similar to Larson's (1988b), raising the V during the derivation as follows:

They suggest (1995: 194) that double object constructions are base-generated and are unrelated to what they call ‘to-constructions’. This recourse to treating the alternation lexically would in itself seem to be a drawback.

Holmberg and Platzack's main purpose in discussing double objects is to demonstrate the effects of the presence or absence of ‘m-case’ (morphological case) in a language. They note that in Icelandic, which has m-case, double objects behave differently from those in Danish, Norwegian, Swedish, and English, languages that don't have m-case. Icelandic direct objects receive accusative case and indirect objects dative, while in the other languages, both NPs have the same (‘accusative’) case. They take the Icelandic facts as evidence that the case on indirect objects is generally not assigned structurally; a conclusion radically at odds with Baker's (1988a, 1988b) assimilating of promoted indirect objects to object position in applicative constructions. In their view, the fact that in Danish, Norwegian, and Swedish, the indirect object retains the same case even in passive and expletive sentences suggests that it is behaving in this respect like a PP.

The authors propose that dative case assignment in Icelandic is the result of a lexical selection feature on the verb. In Mainland Scandinavian, it is achieved by a structural case-licensing rule: “Accusative is licit in Spec-VP” (1995: section 7.4), which recalls a number of Government and Binding analyses which assign accusative case in a lower specifier. Their approach correctly predicts several differences between Icelandic and other Scandinavian languages, based on the presence or absence of this structural case-licensing, and their structures also account for the Barss and Lasnik paradigms. At the cost of an additional special projection ‘ACTP’ for agents, they in fact remove some of the uncertainty concerning multiple Larsonian shells brought out above. They further argue for their structure by proposing that the indirect object exhibits some specifier properties: for example it cannot be deleted or extracted to an A′-position, as expressed earlier in the Restriction in (29). 58

The fact is, most of Holmberg and Platzack (1995) focuses on Icelandic double objects rather than on double objects without m-case. With respect to this contrast, we have been following Den Dikken's (1995c) conclusion, cited here in section 1.2, about the difference between German, with m-case, and English, without it; namely, double objects in an m-case system may require fundamentally different treatment from dative alternations in English and other languages. The largest class of Icelandic double objects, those that occur with give-type verbs, do not alternate with a to-construction, unlike English and Mainland Scandinavian. Moreover, the paradigms for movement with Icelandic double objects are almost the opposite of those in other languages. The two Icelandic objects may invert if the indirect object is a heavy NP (cf. notes 17 and 26 for the exclusion of this in Indonesian and English respectively), and either object may passivize under the same conditions. (Holmberg and Platzack suggest that the heavy NP's status as sentence focus substitutes for the lack of case marker in these sentences.) Any complete theory of indirect objects will, of course, have to account for these contrasts with m-case languages. But the point we developed in section 1.2 is that the paradigms with m-case are so different from ‘bare’ double objects that they are unreliable as a basis for an adequate theory of double objects in languages that lack it.

Holmberg and Platzack's treatment is thus problematic because it is not so much an analysis of the dative alternation in Mainland Scandinavian (which they take to be lexical) as an argumentation for particular types of VP structures and case assignment. In their framework, the double object construction, which they assume does not include an underlying P, is an apparent problem for their claims. Like Larson, they use case assignment in lower Specifiers to explain the grammaticality of double objects in their framework. This contrasts with analyses that assign case to IOs structurally, by an overt or covert underlying P.

subsection.heading: 4.4 Double objects are two arguments in lower NP/DPs
subsection.p: Johnson (1991) proposes that double object constructions are a type of small clause, following Kayne (1984c), with the indirect object acting as the subject of the clause and the direct object acting as a complement. However, the housing of the small clause is a nominal projection, a DP. At least superficially, his structure for double objects and that of Hellan (1991b) are the same.

Johnson's analysis highlights an ‘NP first’ condition on complements, the requirement that complement NPs appear in English, with very few exceptions, immediately following the verb. He explains this requirement by claiming that main verbs in English move out of the VP they head. NP complements are forced to ‘Object Shift’ to a specifier of VP to receive accusative case. They must therefore come before PPs or other non-nominals in the VP complement.

The double object construction poses an apparent counter-example to Johnson's explanation of the ‘NP first’ rule because it does not explain how the second NP can receive case. To avoid this problem, he therefore suggests that the underlying complement structure for double objects contains a single DP, crucially invoking Abney's (1987) ‘DP Hypothesis’ for the structure of noun phrases:

He further proposes that an abstract head &tgr; of the encompassing DP is a case assigner, and thereby able to provide case to its complement (the seeming direct object the check). 59 The V then moves out of VP and the first (indirect) object moves to [Spec, VP] to receive case, as in (73) below, both typical moves in later Government and Binding analyses. This analysis predicts correctly that the first DP in a double object construction will have the position and behavior of a direct object. The structure (72) is also compatible with the Barss and Lasnik paradigms.

Johnson argues that his structure can also explain certain properties of Object Shift in Danish, noted in Vikner (1989): both objects may be shifted together or the first object may move, but the second may not. These movement possibilities are expected if both DP objects are part of a larger DP and if the higher inner DP is accessible to movement, much as a subject of a clause.

However, the structure (72) then incorrectly predicts that both objects may move together in English, yielding ungrammatical sentences like *Whom the check did you give? and *My friend the check was given. Den Dikken and Mulder (1991: section 5) carefully critique Johnson's analysis, enumerating paradigms they feel it fails to handle properly. Johnson's own approach to avoiding “double object movement” uses a variant of Baker's (1988a) argument that Noun Incorporation can sometimes substitute for case assignment. He incorporates the case assigner &tgr; into the verb's D-structure position and then Object Shifts the first DP into [Spec, VP], as before. When this incorporation is blocked, the ‘big DP’ in (73), a simplified version of Johnson's proposed derived structure, must stay in its base position:

The larger DP cannot move in this situation because it contains the trace of &tgr; and cannot move outside its scope without violating Chomsky's (1981: ch. 3) Empty Category Principle. This alternative correctly blocks the movement of both DPs in English, but it would incorrectly block it in Danish. Johnson's system then has to make &tgr;-incorporation obligatory in English but not in Danish. 60

This analysis of double objects has a number of problems, besides the ad hoc properties of the D-head &tgr; in an otherwise unattested type of deep structure DP. For example, it does not address the Restriction (29) on movement of dative NPs to A′-positions, though scenarios for banning A′-bound traces in SPEC might be invoked as in Holmberg and Platzack (1995). It is unclear how to relate Johnson's (72) to the applicative constructions of non-Indo-European languages surveyed in section 3, which share so many properties with English and Scandinavian double object constructions. Nor does (72) tell us why the latter are (close to) synonymous with constructions with overt to-phrases, whose head is unquestionably P (modification by right, stranding behavior, etc.). These problems taken together with those outlined in Den Dikken and Mulder (1991) seem to us to render this ‘DP as small clause’ approach at least in need of serious modification.

subsection.heading: 4.5 Double objects exchange positions
subsection.p: Given the twin needs imposed by the Relational Grammar arguments for indirect object advancement (section 3.2) and the Barss-Lasnik asymmetry requirements, Emonds (1993) reworks his (1972a) proposal that ‘Dative Movement’ is a structure-preserving transformational interchange of a direct and indirect object (i.e., ‘3 to 2 advancement’ accompanied by demotion of the direct object). An appropriate Principles and Parameters reformulation of the original construction-specific rule requires that the interchange be sanctioned by UG, but licensed only in languages with some specific lexical property. His analysis uses a somewhat idiosyncratic understanding of the Projection Principle to predict that dative movement is the only possible type of argument interchange.

The proposed lexical property concerns licensing the empty Ps that are ‘deleted’ in classical dative shift (9), such as English to and for. Emonds (1993) claims that these lexical items enter derivations only in PF, and then only in the absence of any dative shift. 61 That is, in both the shifted and unshifted variants (1) and (2), the entire derivation of LF from Deep Structure contains an empty node [P, +PATH] as in (74), needed only for assigning case to the second NP:

The deep complement structure in (74) is selected by a frame +___NP^NP or +___NP (^NP). The Projection Principle is satisfied whenever a subcategorized YP ‘constitutes’ (= dominates all the lexical material under) a sister of X0 at each relevant level. 62 Like all variants of this Principle, this formulation excludes interchanging any complement with a subject or adjunct or introducing any new ZP under an X′, but it permits interchanging complement NPs (only) around an empty P. Emonds claims this is exactly the formulation that can capture the observed cross-linguistic variation in applicative constructions, which is due to how lexicons license this P.

This structure-preserving interchange of objects satisfies criteria (i)–(v) in section 2.3 for promoted indirect objects in a transformationalist analysis: (i) It accounts for the synonymy of the dative alternations and the cross-linguistic similarity between these alternations and applicative constructions. (ii) While the analysis doesn't decide issues about proper levels for case assignment, it provides two case assigners for two adjacent NPs. (iii) The analysis promotes indirect objects and thus constitutes a basis for explaining their direct object behavior in applicative constructions (section 3.2). (iv) Regarding the unavailability of the promoted NP for A′-movements (29), see below. (v) Finally, the PP structure in (74) provides asymmetric c-command of the second NP by the first, in both shifted and unshifted sequences, and thus accounts for the Barss and Lasnik (1986) paradigms. 63

The underlying PP configuration in (74) is taken to universally define an indirect object, independently of a direct object and the category of the head. If grammatical relations and theta-roles are represented in LF, as is generally assumed, then Emonds's analysis requires that both deep direct and indirect objecthood and/or the corresponding theta-roles be somehow carried through a derivation. Depending on the design of the transformational computation, carrying such information through a derivation may be problematic. 64

A late or PF insertion of Ps such as to and for in the unshifted version of (74) is obligatory because of a general prohibition against unlicensed empty categories. 65 Less straightforward is the obligatory licensing of an empty P in (74) in (only) a shifted or ‘interchanged’ derivation. Emonds suggests that an empty head, for example P in (74), is co-indexed with its sister in underlying structure. The structure-preserving interchange of NPs, while respecting his Projection Principle, then yields the derived configuration (75), where i is the index of the deep direct object and j of the deep indirect object. His claim is that no preposition can be inserted ‘late’ in this shifted derivation because a general condition on PF-insertion of a head requires non-distinct indices between heads and complements: 66

The resulting co-indexed structure (75) then accounts for the crucial cross-linguistic Restriction on A′-extraction (29) of promoted indirect objects as follows. If the NPj in (75) subsequently moves to an A′-position, both its trace and the empty-headed PPj are bound by the same operator. This configuration violates Koopman and Sportiche's (1983) Bijection Principle prohibiting an A′-constituent from locally binding two empty categories (here NPj and [P, PATH]j).

A reviewer has observed that a structure-preserving interchange of double objects does not predict (i) the Scope Freezing of section 3.1.3, (ii) why some English speakers accept immediately postverbal particles with transitive V but not with ditransitive V, or (iii) why second or ‘chômeur’ NPs passivize in some but not all double object systems. However, it is our impression that, aside from ad hoc stipulations, the competing analyses reviewed here do no better in accounting for these three properties. In particular, as pointed out in section 3.1.3, English Scope Freezing seems to be a property of all ‘A-movements’, and is hence irrelevant for choosing among the various A-movement accounts.

Finally, the object interchange in (75), while a necessary condition in this analysis for licensing an empty P, must still not be sufficient to license it, for if it were, every language – including Romance languages – would allow dative movement. In order for P = α to be empty, Emonds proposes that the feature of P (here PATH) must additionally be ‘alternatively realized’ on a (possibly null) applicative affix &bgr;, as in Marantz's (1993) structure (25a). This possibility is allowed by what he claims is a general principle extending at least to morphology:

(76)
Alternative realization:
Language-particular lexicons can alternatively realize a feature F of α on &bgr; only (i) when projections of α and &bgr; are sisters and (ii) when &bgr; is a closed class item, that is, one whose lexical entry includes no (open-class) semantic features.

Since V and PP are sisters in (75), a closed class affixal head of V (&bgr;) is a potential language-specific locus for an alternatively realized PATH feature of a P (α). Alternative realization by applicative affixes, as in Bantu languages, Chinese, Indonesian, etc., is thus a necessary part of this analysis of dative alternations. And as also proposed in Pesetsky (1995), Emonds's analysis requires further that the lexicons of Germanic languages without morphological case furnish null, non-productive applicative affixes for their dative-shift verbs. 67

subsection.heading: 5 Conclusion: what we think we know
subsection.p: In this chapter, we have proceeded through a labyrinth of hypotheses which attempt to explicate an indirect object's transformationally regular ‘promotion to object’ in many languages without productive Case-marking, including English, Dutch, Mainland Scandinavian, and several non-Indo-European VO(O) languages. The generative market place, spanning three decades of debate on the resulting ‘double objects’, indeed offers a rich choice of highly refined products for treating this challenging raw material. In our tour of this bazaar, we have not been sparing in our criticisms, just as the authors reviewed did not spare their predecessors. (In fact, we only barely mentioned some of these critiques, which can be quite telling.)

At the end, we venture to hold strong opinions about certain – we dare say established – cross-linguistic hypotheses, which would defy disconfirmation within even the broadest transformationalist framework. In particular, we are convinced that (i) a structure-dependent theory of abstract case-marking (8) provides superior accounts of double object constructions, and (ii) a null PATH affix akin to overt applicative affixes found outside Indo-European is a good basis for an account of English and Mainland Scandinavian ‘double accusative objects’. 68

We further agree with what we feel are presently four consensus positions:
(51) Consensus on promotion:
Where a language systematically allows two surface NP objects indistinct from accusatives to have different theta-roles, the thematic or deep indirect object is structurally the surface direct object.
(52) Consensus on superiority:
A promoted indirect object surfaces as asymmetrically ‘higher’ than a deep direct object.
(29) Restriction on A′-extraction:
Further movement of a ‘promoted’ indirect object NP unmarked by a P or dative case to a non-argument position is ungrammatical.
(36) Dative passive Restriction:
Passivization of indirect objects (unmarked by any dative case) results from moving NPs already promoted to direct object.

There is still some debate over whether indirect object ‘promotion’ results from transformational movement, but properties of promoted objects discussed in section 3.1, such as the restriction (29) and Scope Freezing, strongly suggest that it does. On the other hand, we have seen in section 4 that the field has not convincingly demonstrated the superiority of any particular account of how the direct object in a double object construction comes to be ‘demoted’. That is, it has not been able to agree on a formal and yet non-ad hoc characterization of what Perlmutter and Postal (1983b) term in Relational Grammar a ‘chômeur’.

subsection.p: Judgments vary widely on (ii) through (iv), especially when wider classes of verbs are considered. Langendoen et al. (1977), advocating the value of questionnaires for settling such disputes, conclude that (ii) is grammatical in some area dialects but ungrammatical in others. Our judgments suggest a generalization of the latter pattern, namely, the deep direct object can't be easily passivized in either type of dative:

li.p: A woman was offered the job.
The guests were finally fixed a lunch.
?A lunch was finally fixed the guests.

subsection.p: Because these facts are murky, theoretical studies have not progressed much in differentiating properties of TO- vs. FOR-datives in English.

The analyses of non-Indo-European double object “applicative” constructions discussed in this chapter all make it clear that indirect objects in double object constructions regularly undergo passivization.

3 Haegeman does not use these terms. Her main theoretical point is to motivate a specific reformulation of ‘Burzio's Generalization’, with which we take no issue.

They argue that only base-generated bare indirect objects can properly license certain immediately adjacent parasitic gap and secondary predication constructions. Our doubts are limited to their structural parallels between Icelandic and Mainland Scandinavian for the order IO–DO.
