To account for this, they propose a language-particular characterization for Icelandic direct objects: “an argument that either immediately follows the verb or is an accusative object.” It would be preferable to maintain a universal definition, that a direct object is an NP sister to V. We can then say that this V characteristically assigns accusative but, in Icelandic, V can also assign quirky case to certain direct objects.
7 Den Dikken accepts Müller's claim that German indirect objects undergo A′-fronting but argues, contra Müller, that this movement should be considered Scrambling and not Dative Movement per se.

8 Structure-Dependent Case (8) does not imply that every NP complement overtly marked for oblique case must be in a PP. Single NP objects may be obliquely case-marked without any PP being present (so-called quirky case).

9 ZMT (note 13) attributes this trichotomy of case assignment to Hjelmslev and, within Government and Binding, to Babby (1980). Some traditional Latin grammar handbooks also reflect this line of thought.

10 The statement holds also for Latin's five-case system if its ablatives and datives, whose forms are in fact always identical in plurals, are analyzed as a single oblique case assigned by P. A theory of autonomous case lacks any basis for explaining this sort of pervasive case syncretism.

subsection.p: Under this view, the distinct dative singular suffixes in Latin are then oblique case allomorphs required when a governing P is both null and unmarked for the feature SOURCE. (Null Ps which are +SOURCE predictably take the ablative.) It then comes as no surprise that (i) overt Latin Ps can require any case except the dative, and (ii) locative DPs mysteriously surface as dative in a Latin poetic style in which locative Ps can ‘drop’. Such consequences are accidental in a scheme of autonomous case.

p.span: 11 Even more restrictively, when a language has no quirky dative direct objects, as in German for example, “there should be no DAT–DAT, DAT–GEN or GEN–GEN verbs in that language.” ZMT (479) credits Czepluch (1982) with making this correct prediction within the GB framework.

12 As pointed out by a reviewer, Romance dative clitics on V are not clitics for PPs or Ps. They correspond rather to the DP or D object of an empty P located in an argument or adjunct position. Hence such clitics can have a floating quantifier, as in this French example: Jean leur a tous donné des livres ‘John them has all given some books’.

13 Jackendoff (1973) argues that P may take two complements (NP + PP), as in the bold PP in It was down the street to Mary that he tossed the ball. It is doubtful that a double object of the type studied here could ever appear in a PP, for example, as *It was down Mary the street that he tossed the ball. That is, the double objects under scrutiny in this study appear only inside XPs headed by V.

14 There seem to be competing styles with respect to the productivity of the English dative alternation. This study and most of the literature focuses on a more conservative style. However, several observers note a less standard style which allows a dative alternation for any verbs consistent with that style:

subsection.p:
(i)
Somebody with more sense better recommend those girls some different make-up.
He went and designed his parents a real nice family room.
By mixing a verb from academic style with the less standard style in (i), one can create sentences acceptable to no one:

(ii)
*Could you reiterate the judge your story, please?
*She caramelized her parents a crème brûlée.

Advocates of treating the English dative alternation as an unpredictable lexical phenomenon sometimes contrast examples like (i), perhaps culled from some observed corpus, with unacceptable examples from the conservative style (ii). This confused methodology proves nothing, since the data are not from a single style of speech.

p.span: 15 Den Dikken (1995c: 158–159) accepts the logical non-equivalence of pairs as in (14) but argues that this does not preclude a transformational relation between them; he suggests that the difference between members of a dative alternation concerns aspect, not theta-roles. Similarly, Hoekstra (1995: note 5) maintains that ‘affectedness’ rather than thematic role distinctions differentiates the pairs.

16 Larson (1990) notes that in examples like Enrico sang Luisa an aria the theme is “for the benefit of the beneficiary.” Thus, this example implies a predication that the aria was for Luisa, but Susan ate vegetables for her mother does not imply that any vegetables were for her mother. Since a direct object NP c-commands a PP complement but not an adjunct, it is plausible that LF c-command of one complement by another directly represents a predication, while the non-c-command relation between an object and an adjunct is meaningless.

17 Chung (1976: 54–56) enumerates many properties of the Indonesian ‘Dative’ rule (i.e., empirical properties of that language's double object construction) which exactly mirror the English double object construction. Lexical accounts have not addressed the issue of expressing these cross-linguistic generalizations.

18 Jackendoff (1990a: 435), in supporting Oehrle's flat structure for English double objects, ascribes many properties of double object sequences simply to their surface order: “An account appealing to linear order generalizes with the greatest of ease.”

subsection.p: But at least some Barss–Lasnik paradigms involve asymmetric c-command of the second object by the first independently of linear order, as shown in more detail in Emonds (1993). In (i), direct object antecedents correctly c-command anaphors, but in (ii) objects of a P fail to c-command the anaphor and hence don't qualify as antecedents:

(i)
Mary described Bill and John to each other/themselves.
She told Bill and John about each other/themselves.
The company reimburses my brothers for each other's expenses.

(ii)
*Mary talked about Bill and John to each other/themselves.
*He argued about John and Mary with each other/themselves.
*He argued with John and Mary about each other/themselves.
*Mary spoke of Bill and John to each other/themselves.
*The company relies on my brothers for each other's expenses.
Unlike the objects of P in (ii), objects of to and from can bind anaphors, perhaps because these latter PP structures are deleted in LF.

p.span: 19 Logically, non-alternating double objects as in English (13) are a base construction or they are not. If they are, then dative movement can simply be a structure-preserving subcase of Move α, using the double NP structure as landing sites. If they are not a base construction, then their only plausible underlying source is indeed an NP–PP sequence, that is, exactly as in a transformational analysis of the dative alternation. Consequently, in spite of their hold on lexicalist advocates, unpaired double object sentences are irrelevant to the whole debate.
20 These are the Projection Principle and the exclusion of complement positions as landing sites.

21 Hoekstra (1995: section 2) first broadly supports and then (sections 5–7) modifies Kayne's empty P proposal. He develops a system in which the empty P can have a different status in different Germanic languages, sometimes being only a sort of case-mark on the NP itself.

22 This null applicative affix effects what derivational morphology calls ‘conversion’, whereby a class of morphemes in one lexical category appears to occur in another (Walinska de Hackbeil 1983). For example, English lexical adjectives such as brown, correct, erect, mature, narrow, obscure, open, quiet, round, secure, slow, smooth, steady, and sour can “convert” to derived verbs by virtue of a null causative affix, akin to the overt causative suffixes -en, -ify, and -ize. (None of these affixes is productive.) Unlike these causativizers, applicative affixes do not change the stem category, but then adjectival -ish and many non-productive diminutive or gender suffixes on N do not change categories either.

23 Pesetsky (1995: 129) points out that “morphophonological restrictions on affixation are familiar, ranging . . . to syllable-counting restrictions like those on the English comparative.” Thus (26) is formally akin to prosaic observations such as: the nominalization suffix -al combines only with final-stressed verbs (arrive, betray, confer, construe, dismiss, etc.); the causativization suffix -en combines only with monosyllables; and the comparative suffix -er is incompatible with non-initial stress or tri-syllabic A. The proposed applicative affix for English also recalls Keyser and Roeper's (1992) proposal that double objects involve a ‘null abstract clitic’.

24 As pointed out by a reviewer, the null affix may combine with lexically ‘inseparable’ unstressed prefixes, which perhaps in Modern English have come to include a(d)-, be-, con-, de-, en-, ex-, for-, per-, pro-, and ex-. In other Germanic languages including Old English, such prefixes generally do not interfere with patterns of uniform initial stress. With this proviso, Herriman's lists of exceptions reduce to a handful of problematic cases: ??telephone your friends an answer, ??guarantee that customer a year of service, ??secure the general the base perimeter.

25 As seen in note 1, passivized indirect objects that are beneficiaries (i.e., Fillmore's for-datives under a movement analysis) are also marginally ungrammatical in some dialects (?Mary was baked a cake). This rarely discussed and poorly understood restriction plays no role in the following discussion.

26 Even though the unacceptabilities are not dramatic, many researchers, including those without commitments to a transformational component, repeatedly reproduce the relevant data in a wide range of English A′-constructions (e.g., Ziv and Sheintuch 1979; Herriman 1995). Herriman's massive empirical study refers to rightward extraposition as ‘Position 3’ and to fronting as ‘Position 4’ and concludes for indirect objects of her Class 1 verbs: “only two examples [of Position 3, extraposition] were found . . . preceded by the . . . object it” (1995: 87); “initial position in the clauses, is . . . of even more doubtful acceptability than position 3, discussed above. Many grammarians . . . exclude this position altogether, while others . . . note that it is highly unusual” (1995: 89). Then: “No examples were found of class 2 indirect objects in these positions [extraposition and fronted] in the corpora” (1995: 118); “none of the corpus examples of class 3 indirect objects occur in positions 3 and 4” (1995: 140); “No examples were found of class 4 indirect objects in positions 3 and 4 in the corpora” (1995: 157).

27 Nonetheless, the weak acceptability judgments supporting the generalization (29) are sometimes disputed for some languages or dialects. For example, Tuller (1984) indicates that the pattern of (32b) is grammatical in Hausa dative applicative constructions. Thus, the accounts proposed for (29) may have to contain a language-particular dimension.

28 Larson (1988b: section 2.3) argues that what Ross (1986) terms Complex NP Shift (blocked for prepositionless indirect objects) is not rightward movement of a heavy NP, but leftward movement of a V′ called ‘Light Predicate Raising’. This term is misleading, as the V′ in these cases has no ‘lightness’ requirement: John [repeatedly sent to the girl who had called] expensive gifts from Selfridge's. The unanswered question is why unstressed direct objects block raising of V′, however light V′ may be: *John sent to her his.
29 Den Dikken further argues that A′-extraction of PP with an empty P is always clause-bound.

30 Whitney's account assumes an early construction-specific formulation of dative movement, so that when the indirect object moves, the deep P of the indirect object in (37) also deletes. The first branching node over the deepest NP trace is then V′; consequently, this trace c-commands any ‘intermediate trace’ in the promoted IO position. Her account perhaps does not spell out clearly enough this role of the loss of P.

subsection.p: If movement of the indirect object does not lead to loss of a branching PP, perhaps the explanation for (29) is rather that intermediate traces always contravene Chomsky's cited principle, by binding potential LF variables in their base position. In fact, this eventuality may account for the exclusion of successive cyclic movement in many languages. Ever since Lasnik and Saito (1984), it seems likely that the only intermediate traces permitted are those that for special reasons delete in the derivation of LF.

p.span: 31 As noted in Oehrle (1976), the order in (48b) can occur in two circumstances: if the IO is a pronoun or if the particle is back. Den Dikken (1995c: section 3.15.2) suggests that such a use of back is part of the DO Theme NP, rather than a head of a complement.
32 We do not agree with Bowers (1993), for whom it is acceptable to float quantifiers off second objects, as in ??We sent John books all in nice packages. See the discussion in section 4.3.3.

33 Although we adopt Marantz's (1993) structural representation (25a) of overt and covert applicative suffixes, his syntactic claims about the structure of double objects strike us as largely arbitrary. Despite the truth-value equivalence of the double object and ‘oblique goal’ constructions V-NP-PP, he derives them from entirely distinct base structures: “the double object constructions will contain two VPs while the oblique constructions contain only one” (1993: 120). His justification for distinct base structures in terms of two different ‘event structures’ is basically discursive rather than evidential. Such a proposal is undermined by the arguments in section 3.1 for the derived nature of the double object construction.

subsection.p: Marantz's different structures, in which the first NP asymmetrically c-commands the second, do account for the paradigms of Barss and Lasnik (1986). But does his analysis achieve anything beyond this? According to his own commentary (1993: 130–131), neither of these two distinct structures with the V between the two objects accounts for the surface word orders; rather, “the linear ordering of constituents is part of the S-structure (SS) to PF interface and not a property of SS.” Nor is any explanation provided for the differing syntax of second objects in two groups of double object languages; applicative verbs are said to govern the second NP differently in the two types, but no independent evidence is given for this stipulation other than the point of departure: when the second NPs passivize and undergo object agreement, the applicative verb governs in one way (as in Koopman 1984), and when they do not, the structurally identical applicative verb governs in another (as in Baker 1988a).

p.span: 34 As he develops his treatment in his chapter 6, Pesetsky finds it advisable to thoroughly recast more familiar conceptions of phrase structure (‘layered syntax’) in terms of his general theory of ‘Cascades’, which lies outside the scope of this work. This development affects his conception of how to properly revise (53).

35 As further support for his approach, Baker points out that applicative constructions are impossible with verbs that cannot assign case, that is, with true intransitives. The only class of apparent Chiche
a intransitives allowing applicative formation includes verbs like sing and dance. Verbs in this group often take ‘cognate’ objects, so presumably they can assign case. Rather than being truly intransitive, they may simply not require a direct object. For further discussion, see Alsina and Mchombo (1990).

36 Note 28 of Emonds (1993) claims that Baker's final version of case theory has eight stipulative properties. Even if two or three such properties succeed in accounting for cross-linguistic variation (e.g., with respect to when demoted direct objects may be passivized), the residue remains unattractive.

37 Overt syntactic incorporation of an argument N does indeed exempt it from the Case Filter, as Baker notes, since the latter is a requirement on surface NPs. Hence the obligatory overt incorporation of otherwise caseless second object in Southern Tiwa would actually seem to confirm the operation of the Case Filter, rather than supporting some kind of exemption from it.

38 Principle (3) from Kayne (1981c): “An anaphor that falls under the binding principles must be connected to an antecedent by an unambiguous path.” To the extent that c-command mimics linear order, as is frequent in analyses using binary trees, imposing a requirement that antecedents are found on ‘unambiguous paths’ amounts simply to saying that an anaphor's antecedent ‘precedes it’ somewhere in the string.

39 Kayne (1984c) also suggests that Stowell's (perhaps English-particular) adjacency requirement on V-object case assignment can be derived from binary branching. He claims that ‘[V Adv] NP’ is not possible if NP is to receive a theta-role and that “V [Adv NP] is impossible” as well. But such structures should then equally well be excluded for the PP complement in the idiomatic (and grammatical) decide quickly on the boat. This grammatical VP then requires either ternary branching or some other stipulation about theta-roles equivalent to (or less general than) Stowell's adjacency on case-marking. Clearly nothing has been gained; the adjacency condition has not been derived from binary branching.

40 Binary branching may well be a serviceable processing principle for projecting adjuncts, coordination structures, external arguments, or the X0-internal structure of compounds. That is, it might function as a kind of ‘Elsewhere Condition’ for tree construction, whenever (56) is not available. But this review concerns precisely those structures for which (56) is available.

41 After briefly mentioning some facts of P stranding in Dutch, Koster (1978b) formulates his Nesting Hypothesis in terms of forbidding certain material on both the left and right of empty categories. The hypothesis can be better compared to Kayne's system by limiting it to forbidding material on the right of empty categories.

42 Small clauses are not needed for defining LF binding domains or for LF subjecthood. The locality imposed by Chomsky's (1981: ch. 3) Binding Principle A involves the presence of a subject in LF. But subjects are generally defined by means of some c-command relation with a phrasal predicate, and make no reference to whether the node immediately dominating them is clausal or not; for example, a direct object c-commands a secondary predication and hence can be its LF subject.

43 Arguments against SC analyses of (57) can also be constructed in terms of gapping. The many studies of this construction in the 15 years following the initial generative study of Ross (1986 [original dissertation 1967]) came to a consensus: well-formed gapping constructions contain two remnant phrases as in (i), but not three as in (ii):

subsection.p:
(i)
Mary turned on the heat, and John [V Ø] the two TVs.
Mary turned on the heat in the morning, and John a bit later.
One thief stole [the TV upstairs] and another [a CD player in the hallway].

(ii)
??Mary turned on the heat in the morning, and John the two TVs a bit later.
??One mover put [the TV] upstairs, and another [a CD player] in the hallway.

Consequently, if SC constituents united direct objects and postverbal particles (or double object sequences), the following gapped clauses would have only two remnant phrases and should hence be well-formed:

(iii)
??Mary turned the heat {on/up}, and John the air conditioning {off/down}.
??Mary sent John Hamlet, and Sue Bill Julius Caesar.
From the marginal status of (iii), one can then only conclude that neither (57) nor double object constructions are best analyzed with single small clause complements.

p.span: 44 The version of Koster's (1978a) Nesting Hypothesis noted in section 4.2.1 can account for the ungrammatical extractions from objects inside nominalizations that Kayne attributes to their status as small clause subjects. Unfortunately, a full comparison of possible alternative analyses of nominalizations is well outside the scope of this review.

45 From the perspective of small clause advocacy, Den Dikken (1995c: section 2.3) also provides a different sort of critique of Kayne's double object structures, especially those containing particles.

46 This requirement of Den Dikken's on small clauses, that they are actually interpreted as predications, seems to us minimal. Yet many small clause structures proposed by Kayne and other advocates, such as SC analyses proposed for the double complement constructions listed in note 51 below, do not fulfil even this basic criterion of semantic compositionality.

47 Cf. tree (52a) in Den Dikken (1995c: 132). For explicitness, we replace his SC and XP with PP and P′ in accord with his standard view that particles are P. Our use of P′ rather than PP is only for making clear the pairings between heads and projections.

48 We observe that the existence of an extra empty P in dative constructions, essentially teasing apart PATH P and PLACE P positions in Dutch, does not in itself justify an SC structure encompassing the two NPs.

49 The lower P travels further up to the head of SC′ after moving from inside the lowest P′ in (63). Den Dikken is careful to show how each step conforms to the theory of movement he adopts. He also offers a critique of Larson's (1988b) analysis for not conforming to restrictions on movement.

50 Larson treats the preposition to in (66) as a ‘pure’ Case marker without extra semantic content, which renders it susceptible to absorption. His account does not explain why overt P absorption after indirect object movement is obligatory (*They sentk Johni [VP tk to ti a letter]), even though a stranded P can remain after NP preposing in English passives (Johni was [VP spoken to ti by Bill]).
52 One of the few discussions of some of these issues is Larson's (1990) response to Jackendoff (1990a); many authors assume shells as in (66) with no attempt to independently justify them.

53 The proposal of Roberts (1985) to the effect that any V must keep on raising until it gets to an I doesn't limit the number of shells; cf. Larson (1988b: 343). Moreover, in some fairly well-supported analyses, e.g., of English participles (Emonds 1985: ch. 2), no Is are paired with V heads.

54 Larson in both articles pursues a rather ingenious account of Heavy NP Shift, claiming the latter doesn't move; instead, his deep V′ constituents, in (66) for example, substitute for a higher empty V ([V′ send to John] any book you can find). This V′-raising prima facie violates Chomsky's (1986) restriction against substituting phrases for heads; to avoid this Larson claims it involves ‘reanalysis’.

subsection.p: His exclusion of a shifted indirect object (*send a book any woman who will accept one) is at bottom a stipulation (1988b: 348). Moreover, other instances of Heavy NP Shift (send John tomorrow any book you can find) are unnaccounted for, as pointed out by Den Dikken (1995c: note 4).

p.span: 55 Larson claims that pseudo-gapping can derive from a “V′ constituent that is elided or replaced with do” (1990: 629). This seems inadequate, since the do of pseudo-gapping is in an I position, not a V position, as seen in (68).
56 It would be strange if a particular grammatical verb, say get, occurred only in one type of clause, say infinitives.

57 While Bowers does provide an account of the Restriction (29) on A′-extraction of the IO in a double object construction (and criticizes Larson's analysis on this count), he must nonetheless stipulate a condition on traces to do so.

58 This argument is actually double-edged, since if the authors use the same VP structure with a to-construction, the direct object will be a specifier of VP. But the latter does not exhibit the same specifier properties in the corresponding sentences; that is, it can be extracted to an A′-position. This problem leads Holmberg and Platzack to redefine the direct object so that it is actually a specialized kind of complement. Their proposal is that the direct object can be a complement of V if it is a sister of V′ and V has not licensed case in V′ (1995: 195). This rule works only if a P is present to assign case to the indirect object.

59 One has to hesitate about a D which assigns case to a DP complement. For example, definite articles and demonstratives never seem to assign case. While various authors have proposed that quantifiers such as all and both have DP complements, such structures are unlike (72) because their specifiers cannot be overt DPs.

60 We must observe that determiners do not typically incorporate into V in the structures studied in Baker (1988a). One may wonder if Johnson's ideas might not be better served with P rather than D as the head of his single complement, along the lines of Den Dikken (1995c).
61 Emonds (1985: chs. 4 and 5, 1993) develops a theory of late or PF lexical insertion for both bound and free morphemes that do not contribute to LF.

62 The late insertion of to and for as heads of complements crucially uses the fact that the Projection Principle does not hold at the level of PF. These two P must differ by some feature, of course; plausibly, it is LOCATION.

63 Since a structure-preserving alternation is a permutation, it necessarily involves two NPs. This may explain why studies of dative and benefactive applicatives (Chung 1976; Aissen 1983: section 5.1; Baker 1988a: section 5.3.2) repeatedly find that indirect object advancement is allowed only with transitive verbs. Analyses such as Hellan's (1991b) and Den Dikken's (1995c), in which bare indirect objects appear only as ‘part of’ the following direct object, correctly predict this in a different way. Alsina and Mchombo (1990: section 3) dispute this generalization on the basis of examples like the following, in which (passivizable) benefactive applicatives seem based on intransitives:

subsection.p:
(i)
Yêsu a-ná-f-ér-a anthu ônse.
1-Jesus 1-PST-die-APPL-Ø 2-people 2-all
‘Jesus died for all people.’

The examples given by these authors involve verbs that are plausibly ‘unaccusative’, die and run. If the construction (i) somehow involves an NP-trace in object position, the generalization can perhaps be maintained.

p.span: 64 Emonds (1993) implicitly rejects the inevitability of a trace with every movement. His analysis is more compatible with theta-roles being assigned to complements ‘phase by phase’, as they are merged with a selecting head. Such interpreted complements are then present within X1 throughout a derivation, including by traces if extracted from X1. No additional restriction immobilizes them within X1.

65 We can conclude from Aissen's (1983) treatment that the Tzotzil lexicon lacks an appropriate directional P, thus ruling out the unshifted version: “ta is the only preposition in Tzotzil and functions variously to introduce locative, temporal, and instrumental phrases” (1983: 287). And: “Any derivation in which the final level of structure contains an indirect object [i.e., an object of P] is ill-formed” (1983: 298).
66 It would be perhaps less stipulative to assimilate the empty co-indexed Pj in (75) to a sort of trace, in the sense that movement generally leaves behind co-indexed covert categories.

67 Another possible locus &bgr; for alternatively realizing PATH (α) is on a closed-class object of P. Certain grammatical Ds may be ‘inherent dative pronouns’ with an optional PATH feature, as in the dialectal John gave it me and The book was sent me (Cf. *The book was sent close friends.) Such Ds could stand alone as bare IOs without undergoing dative movement. This may also explain the dialectal possibility allowing “short” wh-fronting of datives contravening (29), reported in Den Dikken (1995c: section 4.2).
68 As V-final languages, Standard Dutch and West Flemish may or may not fall under generalization (ii) in the text. Cf. section 1.1.
